1 JULY.part4: For he will finish the work, and cut it short in righteousness: because a short work will the Lord make upon the earth.
1 JULY.part5:
From the context of verses 22 to 29, Paul is talking about the work that God will finish. It has to do with unleashing His holy wrath on sins after holding it back from the unbelieving Jews. The quotations in verse 25 from Hosea and verse 27 from Isaiah, point to the fact that even though the children of Israel would be numerous as "the sand of the sea", only a remnant would be saved because most had rejected the Lord Jesus and saw their nationality as guaranteeing God's favour.

To be saved these Jews demanded that "except ye be circumcised after the manner of Moses, ye cannot be saved" [Acts 15:1b]. But the truth is that even a circumcised Jew could not keep the law of Moses for their salvation. The only way is to accept the Lord Jesus as their Saviour and the Promised Messiah by faith, which only a remnant did as recipients of God's election grace.

As for the unbelieving Jews, God "will finish the work, and cut it short in righteousness ... upon the earth", meaning He will speedily carry out His righteous judgment upon an unbelieving Jewish nation. This is a warning that no one can escape if they reject Christ. The only reason judgment is delayed is because "the Lord is not slack concerning his promise, as some men count slackness; but is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance" [2 Peter 3:9]. God will finish His work in His time. He is the Righteous Judge of all the earth. Amen.
1 JULY.part7: For all the promises of God in him are yea, and in him Amen, unto the glory of God by us. - 2 Corinthians 1:20

2 JULY.part4: And as Esaias said before, Except the Lord of Sabaoth had left us a seed, we had been as Sodoma, and been made like unto Gomorrha.
2 JULY.part5:
Here, Paul again cited the Old Testament Scriptures to show that Israel deserved judgment because they had rejected the Lord. Yet the Lord of Sabaoth (the Lord of Hosts), on account of His covenant grace and mercies allowed "a seed" - a remnant to survive. Interestingly a seed gives the picture that it will again grow and multiply by God's grace. If this seed had not been spared, Isaiah says that they would have become like Sodom and Gomorrah, the two cities that God destroyed because of their wickedness. God spared Lot, his wife and their two daughters. But Lot's wife did not make it because she looked back in disobedience.

The point is that even though God is angry at sin and will judge the disobedient, He will keep His covenant promises. This is illustrated in the two historical exiles of Israel and how God brought them back from Egypt and Babylon, and again in their modern-day return to the land on 14th May 1948. God's salvation plan for the remnant of Israel to be a light to the nations has not changed. In Isaiah 49:6 "And he (The LORD) said, It is a light thing that thou shouldest be my servant to raise up the tribes of Jacob, and to restore the preserved of Israel: I will also give thee for a light to the Gentiles, that thou mayest be my salvation unto the end of the earth." God's purpose in preserving a remnant of believing Jews is to proclaim the Gospel of Christ by which sinners are saved by grace. We, being Gentiles, are required to do the same in proclaiming this. With love and gratitude we give ourselves to God to worship and serve Him.
2 JULY.part7: For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek. - Romans 1:16

3 JULY.part4: What shall we say then? That the Gentiles, which followed not after righteousness, have attained to righteousness, even the righteousness which is of faith.
3 JULY.part5:
The purpose and existence of Israel as God's chosen was to testify to the world for Him; they were never meant to hoard God's truth from the world. When The LORD called Abram and made him the recipient of His covenant of grace, He told him, "In thee shall all families of the earth be blessed" [Genesis 12:3b].

It is clear the descendants of Abraham were to actively bear witness for the LORD to the ends of the world. They were to proclaim the Promised Seed - Jesus Christ the Messiah of Israel and Saviour of the world to the Gentiles. But the Jews could not stomach the fact that Gentiles could share the benefits of their belief in the Messiah even though they did not keep God's Law and they were not circumcised. How can that be?

The key is the word "faith". The righteousness the Gentiles attained was neither their own nor the righteousness of their works but the righteousness of Christ which they received by faith in Him. It is all by God's grace as Ephesians 2:8-9 says "For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast." Salvation is through faith in the Lord Jesus, turning from sins, and trusting Him as the Saviour. Romans 10:12: "For there is no difference between the Jew and the Greek: for the same Lord over all is rich unto all that call upon him." Hence the five Solas of the Reformation state that in the light of Scripture alone, we are saved by grace through faith in Christ alone, and to His Glory alone.
3 JULY.part7: For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved. - Romans 10:13

4 JULY.part4: Wherefore? Because they sought it not by faith, but as it were by the works of the law. For they stumbled at that stumblingstone;
4 JULY.part5:
Verse 32 explains why Israel despite meticulously trying to keep God's Law did not attain the righteousness of the Law. This is because no one can keep it perfectly according to Leviticus 18:5: "Ye shall therefore keep my statutes, and my judgments: which if a man do, he shall live in them: I am the LORD."

How then can one be saved since none can obey the Law fully? It is by observing another portion of the Law based on faith which is the Day of Atonement when worshippers would bring their animal sacrifices before the Lord.

As we read in Hebrews 10:1,4, "For the law having a shadow of good things to come, and not the very image of the things, can never with those sacrifices which they offered year by year continually make the comers thereunto perfect ... For it is not possible that the blood of bulls and of goats should take away sins." The only way to take away our sins is to look to Jesus Christ by faith for He is "The Lamb of God which taketh away the sin of the world" [John 1:29b]. Sadly, Israel put their faith not in Christ but in their "ability to keep the Law". He is the stone Israel stumbled and tripped on.

Are you being told that there are things you must do beyond putting your faith in Christ in order to be saved? If so, perhaps you have not fully trusted in Jesus as Lord but depending on yourself. May you put your faith in Christ today and become a "stepping stone" instead for many to come to Christ.
4 JULY.part7: Let us draw near with a true heart in full assurance of faith, having our hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience, and our bodies washed with pure water. - Hebrews 10:22

5 JULY.part4: As it is written, Behold, I lay in Sion a stumblingstone and rock of offence: and whosoever believeth on him shall not be ashamed.
5 JULY.part5:
Paul cites from the Scriptures "as it is written" to show that Jesus is that foundation rock God laid in Sion which became a stone of stumbling and rock of offence to the unbelieving Jewish nation. He quotes from Isaiah to substantiate this, "And he shall be for a sanctuary; but for a stone of stumbling and for a rock of offence to both the houses of Israel, for a gin and for a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem" [Isaiah 8:14]. "Therefore thus saith the Lord GOD, Behold, I lay in Zion for a foundation a stone, a tried stone, a precious corner stone, a sure foundation: he that believeth shall not make haste" [Isaiah 28:16]. In contrast to unbelieving Israel, Paul tells us that believers in Christ "are built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Jesus Christ himself being the chief corner stone" [Ephesians 2:20].

The chief corner stone is the most important stone in the building because upon it everything else is aligned and supported. Because of unbelief, Israel stumbled over Jesus their Messiah and He became a rock of offence. They were offended by His words in John 5:40 "And ye will not come to me, that ye might have life". They were spiritually blind and refused to see who Jesus is even though they witnessed His many mighty miracles with their own eyes. Failure to accept Jesus causes a person to trip (stumble). But understanding who He is, accepting and trusting Him by faith will lead to life everlasting. Is the Lord Jesus Christ the Son of the living God to you?
5 JULY.part7: Our Lord Jesus said, "Search the scriptures; for in them ye think ye have eternal life: and they are they which testify of me." [John 5:39]

6 JULY.part4: Brethren, my heart's desire and prayer to God for Israel is, that they might be saved.
6 JULY.part5:
Despite the unbelief of his countrymen and the harsh treatment he received from them, apostle Paul did not dismiss them nor wish them an evil end. He lovingly regarded his "brethren", expressing his heartfelt desire for their salvation for which he would pray to God.

Prayer is the ordained means accorded to man to intercede for the salvation of his fellow-man. We can imagine Paul's prayer to be pleading, earnest and persistent, just as he wrote to the Thessalonians to pray continually [1 Thessalonians 5:17]. It behoves us to pray likewise even as God moves us to pray for the salvation of others, trusting that God will save those for whom He moves us to pray because He desires all men to be saved [1 Timothy 2:3-4]. Paul's foremost calling was to be the apostle to the Gentiles [Romans 11:13; Acts 9:15], but that did not diminish his love and heart's desire for the salvation of his fellow Jews.

He was aware Jesus had declared that "salvation is of the Jews" [John 4:22]. Wherever he went, he would first preach the gospel in a synagogue if he could find one [Acts 9:20; 13:14; 14:1]. Paul remembered how Jesus on the cross prayed "Father, forgive them for they know not what they do;" and Stephen in his dying breath cried aloud "Lord lay not this sin to their charge" [Acts 7:60]. The Lord and Stephen prayed even for their murderers. Paul's "heart's desire" was for the salvation even of his countrymen who persecuted him. May God grant us a heart like Paul's to desire and pray for the salvation of all men.
6 JULY.part7: But I say unto you, Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you. - Matthew 5:44

7 JULY.part4: Brethren, my heart's desire and prayer to God for Israel is, that they might be saved.
7 JULY.part5:
Prior to his conversion, the apostle Paul was a die-hard Pharisee who strongly rejected and opposed Jesus Christ. He persecuted Christ's followers ferociously, throwing men, women and children into prison, even having some killed [Acts 8:1-3]. But on the road to Damascus, Paul was confronted by the risen Lord who in His grace and love saved Paul. Having received salvation grace, Paul became a changed man. His deep gratitude and love for his Saviour moved him to dedicate the rest of his life to his Master's cause. With a newfound burden for unsaved souls, Paul embarked on his missionary journeys preaching the Gospel throughout Asia Minor and Europe to the saving of souls.

While we were yet sinners lost and undone, God demonstrated His amazing love towards us, and Jesus with great compassion for our souls, died on Calvary's cross to save us [John 3:16; Romans 5:8-9]. We too like Paul ought to respond to our Saviour's love and grace with a similar burden for souls.

We pray to God for all sorts of things; for "daily bread", physical needs, safety, comfort, success, peace for ourselves and families; for righteousness and wisdom for our rulers. While these benefits make our life here comfortable, they do not count for eternity. What counts is where our souls will be - in Heaven with God our Heavenly Father or in hellfire with the devil. The Lord Jesus has said, "For what is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul?" [Matthew 16:26a].

May the Lord grant us a burden for souls, earnestly proclaiming the good news of salvation and praying for the lost.
7 JULY.part7: Let him know, that he which converteth the sinner from the error of his way shall save a soul from death, and shall hide a multitude of sins. - James 5:20

8 JULY.part4: For I bear them record that they have a zeal of God, but not according to knowledge.
8 JULY.part5:
Paul earnestly desired and prayed for the salvation of his fellow Jews who were zealously religious but yet far from God. From his personal life experience as a radical Pharisee steeped in traditional Judaism before his conversion, he knew what it meant. Most Jews took their religion very seriously, having great zeal for their ancestral traditions [Galatians 1:13-14]. Paul admitted that before his conversion, he was proud of his heritage, his tribe, his upbringing and rabbinical training. He zealously and legalistically fulfilled the outward demands of the law. Paul thought himself righteous and godly even as he persecuted the church.

But Paul, like his fellow Pharisees, was far from God. Though taught by the leading theologian Gamaliel, Paul, like many other Jewish leaders had only a certain kind of knowledge (gnosis), an intellectual knowledge of the demands of the law but not the spiritual knowledge (epignosis) that comes from a personal and saving knowledge of God.

Blinded by ignorance, and hardened in their hearts by pride and arrogance, they rejected the teachings of His Son the Lord Jesus, and persecuted Him and His followers. It was only by God's grace that Paul came to a realisation that his zeal was misguided. The risen Lord confronted him on the road to Damascus and caused him to know that Jesus of Nazareth whom he was persecuting was indeed the Son of God. The religious zeal of the unbelieving Jews could not save them if they failed to know and believe this.

May the Lord grant to us spiritual discernment and keep us in the path of Truth.
8 JULY.part7: Open thou mine eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of thy law. - Psalm 119:18

9 JULY.part4: For I bear them record that they have a zeal of God, but not according to knowledge.
9 JULY.part5:
While the Jews had a "zeal for God", they were unsaved because their zeal was not based on correct knowledge and Paul felt compelled to pray for their salvation. Their problem was they were ignorant of God's righteousness and their own sinfulness. Like Luther centuries later, they mistakenly thought that God requires of man "human righteousness", such as developing a good character manifested in "good works" through human effort, not realizing that human "good works" are but filthy rags before the thrice holy God. "But we are all as an unclean thing, and all our righteousnesses are as filthy rags; and we all do fade as a leaf; and our iniquities, like the wind, have taken us away." [Isaiah 64:6]

True salvation is not merely a renovation of one's character by adopting a higher standard of morality. It involves the working of the Holy Spirit in convicting the sinner's heart of sin, bringing him to repentance, and regenerating him with new life in Christ. He is transformed into a new creature with a renewed mind. "Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new." [2 Corinthians 5:17]

The nation of Israel was the most privileged of all people on earth. Chosen by God, they were blessed by the revelation of God's Word and His promises. But lacking a true knowledge of who He was, their zeal for God through pride in their lineage, ancestral traditions, and man-made laws generated a religiosity that was vain and empty, devoid of salvation grace. Only the Gospel of Christ "is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth." [Romans 1:16]
9 JULY.part7: I am the way, the truth, and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by me. - John 14:6

10 JULY.part4: For they being ignorant of God's righteousness, and going about to establish their own righteousness, have not submitted themselves unto the righteousness of God.
10 JULY.part5:
Some years ago, this writer was driving back to Singapore from Ipoh in Perak, Malaysia, and had to make a stop in Kuala Lumpur. Resuming our journey, we tried to get onto the newly-completed section of the North-South Highway from Kuala Lumpur to Seremban, the next major stop on the highway. We saw some blue signs directing us to Seremban and dutifully followed them. However, it soon became apparent those signs did not lead us to the highway; and it was only when we reached a small town called Kajang that we learnt that to get onto the North-South Highway, we needed to follow the green-coloured signs, not the blue ones.

In this verse, Paul explained that his fellow Jews were making the same kind of mistake. No matter how zealous they were and how hard they tried to obey the Old Testament laws, they would not be able to meet the Holy God's high standards of righteousness which require perfect obedience to His Law. They were ignorant of the perfect righteousness God had provided in the person of Jesus Christ and tried to establish their own righteousness by studiously following a set of manmade rules and rituals.

Little wonder our Lord told His disciples that unless their righteousness exceeded that of the scribes and Pharisees, they will never enter the kingdom of heaven [Matthew 5:20]. God's righteousness is a gift we can only receive by faith. It is not a reward for our own works-righteousness.
10 JULY.part7: For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast. - Ephesian 2:8-9

11 JULY.part4: For they being ignorant of God's righteousness, and going about to establish their own righteousness, have not submitted themselves unto the righteousness of God.
11 JULY.part5:
Paul said that his countrymen, the Jews, had tried to establish their own way of righteousness. They tried to make themselves acceptable to God through rituals, ceremonies, laws, and works. They sought to save themselves by being as religious as they could. They made up many rules and regulations and followed them strictly. They believed God would accept them, especially since they were descendants of Abraham [Matthew 3:9]. Paul himself was a perfect example of such a person who had "confidence in the flesh". He was "circumcised the eighth day, of the stock of Israel, of the tribe of Benjamin, an Hebrew of the Hebrews; as touching the law, a Pharisee; Concerning zeal, persecuting the church; touching the righteousness which is in the law, blameless" [Philippians 3:5-6].

But when the Lord removed his spiritual blindness through "the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus" [Philippians 3:8], all he wanted was to "be found in him, not having mine own righteousness, which is of the law, but that which is through the faith of Christ, the righteousness which is of God by faith" [Philippians 3:9]. In other words, he now "submitted himself unto the righteousness of God."

The Jews were not the only ones who held this wrong understanding of righteousness. All the man-made religions of the world teach the same thing. They desperately need the light of the Gospel. But how can they hear the Gospel without a preacher [Romans 10:14]? Pray that God will send you to preach the Gospel to those who need it.
11 JULY.part7: And he said unto them, Go ye into all the world, and preach the gospel to every creature. - Mark 16:15

12 JULY.part4: For they being ignorant of God's righteousness, and going about to establish their own righteousness, have not submitted themselves unto the righteousness of God.
12 JULY.part5:
The word "righteous" used in the everyday context, refers to a person who is morally upright in the eyes of people around him. In the Old Testament, other adjectives like upright and blameless - or "perfect" in the case of the King James Version - are also employed to describe such persons. Job was a good example. The opposite of such a person would be the wicked or evildoers described in Psalm 37. However, no matter how "perfect" such a man is, he is still a sinner and can never achieve the righteousness required by a righteous and holy God. That's why Paul says in Romans 3:10 and 23 that "there is none righteous, no, not one ... for all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God". Compared to God's righteousness, the works of righteousness of all the religions of the world are like filthy rags [Isaiah 64:6].

God's righteousness differs from the manconceived works-righteousness of the world in a number of ways. Firstly, it is not earned, but is given through a vicarious exchange. Christ takes on our sin - in fact He became our sin - and in exchange, we receive His righteousness. To be declared righteous in God's sight you must be willing to put all your sins on Christ and take up his righteousness. Secondly, it cannot be bought by us, but it has been paid for ... by the precious blood of our Saviour. Thirdly, it is not temporary but eternal. God will remember our sins no more.

The tragedy for the Jews is that they refused to accept Christ.
12 JULY.part7: For he hath made him to be sin for us, who knew no sin; that we might be made the righteousness of God in him. - 2 Corinthians 5:21

13 JULY.part2: Christ, the End of the Law
13 JULY.part4: For Christ is the end of the law for righteousness to every one that believeth.
13 JULY.part5:
In saying that Christ is the end of the law, Paul is not saying there is no more need for the moral law in our lives; that it was annulled and Christians can now sin all they want. That Christians should lead holy lives and hate sin is something taught by Christ Himself and all the New Testament writers. What Paul means by that statement is that we have been released from the penalty and condemnation of the law. Christ took the sins of man upon Himself to bear the condemnation they deserved.

Christ also ended the law in the sense that He fulfilled and completed the law perfectly. Although He was born into our world as a human and suffered the physical frailties and temptations as a man, He was sinless and obeyed every rule and requirement of the law. Christ also ended the law in that He is the object toward which the law pointed. All the ceremonies, sacrifices, offerings, and purifications required by the Mosaic Law pictured and pointed toward Christ. The law was never intended to be the way to become righteous and acceptable to God. Rather it showed them their own sinfulness and inadequacy. The law was given to point and lead men to Christ, who is the righteousness of God. The law was but a shadow of the real substance that was to come [Colossians 2:17].

It is vital to note that Christ is the end of the law for righteousness only to those who truly believe and trust in Him. When we do that, God not only removes our sins, He also imputes Christ's righteousness in us. Hallelujah, what a Saviour!
13 JULY.part7: There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit. - Romans 8:1

14 JULY.part4: For Christ is the end of the law for righteousness to every one that believeth.
14 JULY.part5:
To the natural man, the message of the Gospel is foolishness [1 Corinthians 1:18]. How can we receive forgiveness for our sins simply by believing and calling upon the name of Christ? Certainly, there must be something we need to do to earn it. Hence, many Christians believe that in addition to believing, we have to do good works. This is an insult to the cross of Calvary. Just before He breathed His last, the Lord declared; "It is finished" [John 19:30]. The work of redemption has been completed. Salvation is a finished work. We cannot and do not need to do anything to add to it.

Then there are those who argue that we need to do good works and live holy lives so as not to lose our salvation citing James 2:26 which says, "faith without works is dead". This again is not what the Bible teaches. This is a misinterpretation. James did not say "salvation without works is dead." He is simply asserting that our profession of faith should be evident by our lives. The clear teaching of the Bible is that, when a person comes to know Christ as his Saviour, he is brought into a relationship with God that guarantees his salvation to be eternally secure.

We do not need to work to earn our salvation. All God is looking for is simply our belief in Christ. In fact, He does not even need us to promise to be good for the rest of our lives. We are saved by believing in the promises that He has made to us.
14 JULY.part7:
His robes for mine:
O wonderful exchange!
Clothed in my sin,
Christ suffered 'neath God's rage.
Draped in His righteousness, I'm justified.
In Christ I live, for in my place He died.
- His Robes for Mine by Chris Anderson.

15 JULY.part4: For Moses describeth the righteousness which is of the law, That the man which doeth those things shall live by them.
15 JULY.part5:
Romans 10:5, which is a paraphrase of Leviticus 18:5, seems to suggest that God's covenant with Israel through Moses is merely a repackaging of the Covenant of Works that God made with Adam at the dawn of creation. God's test for Adam in the Covenant of Works was obedience. Simply, do and live.

However, the contexts in which the two Covenants were established show that they are radically different in their nature and intention. The covenant God made with Adam after the fall - and formalised in the giving of the Ten Commandments - is known as the Covenant of Grace.

God prefaced His giving of the Law to the people with these words: "I am the LORD thy God, which have brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage" [Exodus 20:12]. In other words, the Ten Commandments were not given so that the Israelites could be delivered if they obeyed God's commandments. Rather, the Law was given to a people, whom God had already redeemed from bondage. The Law was not given to strangers, but to a people God had chosen to be His own - God is their God [Leviticus 18:2]; they are not to live like the Egyptians or the Canaanites [Leviticus 18:3]. The Israelites are to do God's judgments, and keep God's ordinances, to walk therein ... keep God's statutes, "which if a man do, he shall live in them: I am the LORD" [Leviticus 18:4-5].

In other words, God's Law was not given as a Covenant of Works. It is not "do so that you can live". God's law is a covenant of grace - "do because you have been given new life".
15 JULY.part7: The Covenant of Grace is God's covenant of love with His people. He first loved us, and in grateful response, we love Him by obeying His Word.

16 JULY.part2: The Law and the First Man
16 JULY.part4: For Moses describeth the righteousness which is of the law, That the man which doeth those things shall live by them.
16 JULY.part5:
God gave instruction to Adam, "Of every tree of the garden thou mayest freely eat: But of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, thou shalt not eat of it: for in the day that thou eatest thereof thou shalt surely die" [Genesis 2:1617]. Adam was to obey God's command. This is the Covenant of Works, which the Westminster Shorter Catechism defines as a special act of God's providence: "When God had created man, he entered into a covenant of life with him, upon condition of perfect obedience; forbidding him to eat of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, upon pain of death" (Question 12).

God's command was singular and simple. By giving this command, God placed Adam and Eve on probation. If they obey God's command, they will receive eternal life in heaven. Disobedience on their part would result in banishment from the garden, forfeiture of life, and the curse of death.

However, the Covenant of Works is also a promise (a Covenant) of God's Grace. A. A. Hodge says that "the very act of creation brings the creature under the obligation to the Creator, but it cannot bring the Creator into obligation to the creature. Creation itself, being a signal act of grace, cannot endow the beneficiary with a claim for more grace."

In the covenant between God and Adam, it was required of Adam to obey God, and in return, God would keep Adam in close communion with Him. To put it another way: if Adam had obeyed God, God would surely bless Adam, but God's blessings upon Adam is not the result of Adam's obedience. God's blessings upon Adam are - in themselves - an act of grace on the part of God.
16 JULY.part7: It is all of God's grace, nothing but His grace.

17 JULY.part2: The Law and the Fallen Man
17 JULY.part4: For Moses describeth the righteousness which is of the law, That the man which doeth those things shall live by them.
17 JULY.part5:
The demand of the covenant God made with Adam, the representative of the human race, is plain and clear: perfect obedience to God's revealed command [Genesis 2:16-17]. The command not to eat from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil is what some theologians call a positive law, which is a reflection of the Moral Law written within his heart. Thus, when God commanded Adam not to eat the forbidden fruit, He was commanding Adam to act in accordance with the Moral Law in his heart. And God expected Adam's perfect and perpetual obedience to His command.

After the Fall, God's demands did not change. God still calls for perfect and perpetual obedience, failing which the penalty is death [Leviticus 18:45]. These words quoted by Paul - "That the man which doeth those things shall live by them" - is saying that the man who continuously keeps the law shall live - a demand for perfect and perpetual obedience, failing which the curse is death [Romans 6:23a]. Paul adds, "Cursed is every one that continueth not in all things which are written in the book of the law to do them." [Galatians 3:10]

That is man's problem. The law which promises eternal life also demands perfect obedience in every aspect of our lives. Justification by the works of the law is impossible because no man is able to obey the law perfectly because we are born with a sinful nature on account of Adam's sin [Psalm 51:5]. The law that demands absolute perfection also condemns the least transgression [James 2:10].

The law entered and sin abounds in our conscience so that we might know our sin personally and intensively. Our hope is not in our keeping of the law; our hope is in God's grace, because where sin abounds, His grace abounds much more.
17 JULY.part7: The law knows no mercy; it knows no mitigation, it overlooks not even the smallest breach, or the smallest deficiency. One guilty thought or desire would condemn for ever. - Robert Haldane

18 JULY.part2: The Law and the Second Man
18 JULY.part4: For Moses describeth the righteousness which is of the law, That the man which doeth those things shall live by them.
18 JULY.part5:
In Romans 10:5, we learn that a man could be justified by the law on the condition he kept the law perfectly and perpetually - of course an impossibility. In Romans 10:4, we learn that the only Man who did that is the Lord Jesus Christ. He is "the end of the law for righteousness to every one that believeth".

He was "made of a woman, made under the law" [Galatians 4:4] meaning He was born under the expectations of the covenant God made with Adam. In His life, Christ kept the law perfectly to the jot and tittle. In His death, Christ "redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us: for it is written, Cursed is every one that hangeth on a tree" [Galatians 3:13].

To accomplish the work of justification, Christ needed to obey, and He needed to die. He lived righteously to fulfil the precepts of the law, and He died to fulfil the penalty of the law.

Thus, by His life and death, we who can never be justified by our works of the law now have the righteousness of Christ imputed to us by faith. On account of what Christ has done, and by faith in His finished work, we are justified. Paul says - "Therefore as by the offence of one judgment came upon all men to condemnation; even so by the righteousness of one the free gift came upon all men unto justification of life. For as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners, so by the obedience of one shall many be made righteous" [Romans 5:18-19].

What a wonderful Saviour! What a relief for sinners!
18 JULY.part7: Christ is the last Adam, He did what the first failed to do, and He did for us what we cannot do [1 Corinthians 15:45].

19 JULY.part4: For Moses describeth the righteousness which is of the law, That the man which doeth those things shall live by them.
19 JULY.part5:
When Paul quoted Leviticus 18:5, he did not take it to mean a promise of life on the basis of obedience. That verse does not offer a promise of life through obedience. The intent of it is to show us that the law is to be our way of life; it is not a way to life through our obedience. The way to life and righteousness is faith in Christ, to whom the Law points and leads [Romans 10:4].

This "do-and-live" principle is not the Gospel of Christ. The Bible is explicitly clear that salvation is not based on what we have done and what we must continuously and perfectly do. Our salvation stands on the ground of what our Lord Jesus has done. However, the redeemed person must abide by the "live-and-do" principle.

In John 8:4, we read about the Pharisees who brought before Jesus a woman caught in the act of adultery. They expected Jesus to pass judgment upon her. But our Lord said, "He that is without sin among you, let him first cast a stone at her" [John 8:7]. And as the accusers quietly slinked away, our Lord Jesus said to the woman, "Neither do I condemn thee: go, and sin no more" [John 8:11].

The sequence of the words in John 8:11 makes a world of difference. Our Lord Jesus did not say to her, "Go and sin no more, I do not condemn you." In fact, our Lord's words were quite the opposite, "I do not condemn you, go and sin no more." What a relief it must have been for the woman, and what a relief for us sinners. In Christ, we are no longer condemned so that we may live and do!
19 JULY.part7: "Although true believers be not under the law as a covenant of works, to be thereby justified or condemned; yet is it of great use to them, as well as to others; in that, as a rule of life informing them of the will of God and their duty, it directs and binds them to walk accordingly..." [Westminster Confession of Faith, Chapter 19.6]

20 JULY.part4: But the righteousness which is of faith speaketh on this wise, Say not in thine heart, Who shall ascend into heaven? (that is, to bring Christ down from above:)
20 JULY.part5:
What is this righteousness Paul speaks about? We may best understand it by comparing it with its opposite number - the "righteousness of works."

Almost all religions believe doing good works, living an upright life and performing certain rituals earn a person merit which will offset the bad things they do. In the final accounting when all these are weighed, if the scales tip in favour of the good, then the outcome (eternal or otherwise) for that person will be favourable. Human efforts to gain the approval of some deity even the God of the Scriptures is the righteousness of works which even the majority of Jews, privileged recipients of God's Law in the Old Covenant, mistakenly believed in under the teaching of their teachers, the Pharisees.

The righteousness which God requires is absolute and perfect because He is holy and cannot tolerate sin. If man cannot keep perfectly the Law so as to be sinless, then he does not make the grade. Yet God in His mercy and grace made a way of deliverance by giving sinners a gift. As the apostle said in Ephesians 2:8-9: "For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast". Faith in what or who? Faith in the Saviour sent from heaven, for it is only His sacrifice which is able to atone for our sins and His righteousness put on our account when we believe and accept Him by faith which makes us acceptable in God's eyes. When God looks at sinners as we are, He sees the blood and righteousness of His Son covering us. Believing and accepting Him with all our heart is how we obtain His righteousness, the righteousness of faith.
20 JULY.part7: Therefore by the deeds of the law there shall no flesh be justified in his sight: for by the law is the knowledge of sin. - Romans 3:20

21 JULY.part2: Journey into Heaven and the Deep
21 JULY.part4: But the righteousness which is of faith speaketh on this wise, Say not in thine heart, Who shall ascend into heaven? (that is, to bring Christ down from above:) Or, Who shall descend into the deep? (that is, to bring up Christ again from the dead.)
21 JULY.part5:
To "search high and low" is a familiar idiom meaning to "look everywhere strenuously". This in essence is what Paul is talking about in today's verses where he paraphrases Deuteronomy 30:12-14 when Moses commanded the Israelites to heed God's covenant and His commandments which had been clearly revealed to them so that there was no need for them to be searching high and low or attempting to do what only God can do.

What is acceptable in God's eyes is a righteousness based on faith - faith in the only way He has prescribed for admittance into His kingdom; faith in the righteousness of the sinless atoning sacrifice He Himself provided which is graciously imputed (put upon) the sinner so that his sins are covered; faith in the only Saviour, whom John the Baptist hailed "the Lamb of God which taketh away the sin of the world." [John 1:29]

As the covenant was made by God with Israel and the Law given to them before, now God had sent His Son in person thus fulfilling the prophecies of the promised Messiah which the Old Testament Law and practices pointed to. God has done the impossible for them. His righteousness was not something they had to search for or work for by journeying to the highest heavens and deepest deep (literally, abyss or bottomless pit). Christ had come and His salvation work was completed by His death and resurrection to the right hand of God the Father.

What every sinner needs today is in the Gospel that has been given. What he needs is to believe and accept by faith the good news of salvation in Jesus Christ offered to all who will believe.
21 JULY.part7: Jesus saith unto him, I am the way, the truth, and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by me. - John 14:6

22 JULY.part4: But what saith it? The word is nigh thee, even in thy mouth, and in thy heart: that is, the word of faith, which we preach.
22 JULY.part5:
Paul continues with his reference to Deuteronomy 30:11-14 and asks his readers, "What does it say?" It said, "It is not hidden from thee, neither is it far off." Israel in Moses' day knew God's commandments and the righteousness He required. For the people of Paul's letter and everyone thereafter, Jesus Christ the Living Word had come and His message of amnesty to God's enemies was proclaimed by Him, His apostles and disciples. The righteousness of the Saviour made available to all who by faith, believe was accessible and achievable, and the inevitable judgment awaiting all who rejected it was also made clear. The types and figures of salvation in the Old Testament Scriptures which they knew well, were now perfected in the Son of God who had dwelt among them. The requirement to receive this righteousness which would save was not by man's work and human efforts, but by simple believing faith in the Man of righteousness Himself, Christ Jesus.

This was the message Paul and other faithful men preached. This is the same message we hold today in God's written Word, the Bible. We have faithful preachers, and we have all the means by which this Word of faith is made available to people everywhere. Truly, the word is near us, even in our mouths and we know it in our hearts. There really is no excuse. What then?

For us who know Him, let this knowledge cause in us the desire to spread this good news. For those who have heard but still resist, doubt or have your own ideas of escaping the judgment to come, may you heed it, believe and accept by faith this Saviour, the Lord Jesus and have the joy and assurance of His salvation.
22 JULY.part7: So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God. - Romans 10:17

23 JULY.part4: That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.
23 JULY.part5:
Believe it or not, like it or not, the matter of one's salvation is a matter with eternal consequences. Who needs to be saved? Every man and woman - for all have sinned [Romans 3:23] and there is none righteous [Romans 3:10].

Why is there a need to be saved? Because the wages of sin is death [Romans 6:23] and the soul that sinneth, it shall die [Ezekiel 18:4].

Who is able to save? Only one Saviour and one way [John 14:6]. God in His love sent His Son to us to be the way back to Him. Jesus humbled Himself as a man to die as the substitutionary atonement for our sins [Philippians 2:7-8]. He alone is the Saviour and mediator between God and men [1 Timothy 2:5] because only the sinless Second person of the Triune Godhead could do what no one else could and meet the holy standard God requires.

How can the sinner be saved? To the Philippian jailor, the apostle declared, "Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ, and thou shalt be saved, and thy house" [Acts 16:30-31]. To the Roman Christians, he writes, "That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved." Believing faith in Christ as the Risen Saviour and submission to Him as Lord of our lives are essential requirements of true salvation.

Jesus told the crowds that thronged Him, because they saw His miracles, "This is the work of God, that ye believe on him whom he hath sent." Then He said to them, "I am the bread of life: he that cometh to me shall never hunger; and he that believeth on me shall never thirst" [John 6:29, 35]. Do you believe this too?
23 JULY.part7: Salvation is not hard to understand if we are humble and exercise faith in what God has said. - John 3:16-18

24 JULY.part4: That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.
24 JULY.part5:
What confession is the apostle talking about here? It is not the admission of guilt this word commonly refers to. Rather it is meant the profession of belief in a person and acknowledging one's acceptance of and submission to him.

Who must the sinner confess? The resurrected Lord Jesus Christ.

What does confessing Him entail? It entails understanding, belief, acceptance and submission. We must understand in our minds who we are professing faith in and what He requires of us. He is the Lord, the sinless Son of God. But this head knowledge is not enough. We must believe in our hearts who He is and what He says. We must accept Him personally as our Master with absolute authority over us and be in agreement with all He says to us in His inspired and inerrant Word - the Bible. He has authority over our lives. The doctrines contained in His Word are to be obeyed and are for our good. If He is truly Lord of our lives, then we are to submit to Him in reverence and obedience, with trust and confidence.

It is also highlighted here that He is the Risen Lord. This is the pre-eminent doctrine of the Gospel. If Jesus had remained dead, then He was powerless over death and certainly powerless to save anyone from death. But He is alive, which validates the truth and authority of everything else He says in His Word. We confess the Saviour who lives today in heaven and who will return again as His Word says.
24 JULY.part7: Whosoever shall confess that Jesus is the Son of God, God dwelleth in him, and he in God. - 1 John 4:15

25 JULY.part4: For with the heart man believeth unto righteousness; and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation.
25 JULY.part5:
Our hearts are "deceitful above all things and desperately wicked" [Jeremiah 17:9]. Furthermore, "out of the heart of men, proceed evil thoughts, adulteries, fornications, murders, thefts, covetousness, wickedness, deceit, lasciviousness, an evil eye, blasphemy, pride, foolishness" [Mark 7:21-22]. How can we whose hearts are evil have faith in the Lord Jesus who is holy, righteous, good and pure? By God's grace and mercy, God elected us to be His children. The Holy Spirit transformed us, regenerated our hearts and converted our souls. God gave us a new heart to know Him and acknowledge Him as King of our lives [Jeremiah 24:7]. We repented of our sins, and forsook our idols and our lusts, realising these foolish pursuits led to eternal destruction.

We thank our Lord Jesus for dying on the cross in our place, even though He was sinless and perfect so that His righteousness can be imputed to us. By His death and resurrection, we have reconciliation with God and the blessed hope of eternal life in heaven.

Our hearts are not just the seat of our affections and emotions but also the centre of our intellect and will. When our hearts believe in Jesus, it is not a momentary infatuation or a casual feeling but a whole-hearted, sincere love for Him, for His love and the great sacrifice He made for us. By believing in Him, we acknowledge Jesus Christ's deity and His lordship over our life. Dear reader, do you believe in Jesus? Will you surrender your heart to Him and trust Him alone to be your Saviour?
25 JULY.part7: Take heed, brethren, lest there be in any of you an evil heart of unbelief, in departing from the living God ... To day if ye will hear his voice, harden not your hearts, as in the provocation. - Hebrews 3:12, 15

26 JULY.part4: For with the heart man believeth unto righteousness; and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation.
26 JULY.part5:
Confession can mean an admission of one's guilt. The meaning here is to profess or declare our faith and belief in the saving grace of Jesus Christ.

Paul tells us that sincere and wholehearted faith and trust in Jesus Christ results from belief in His power to save us. That same genuine and unshakeable belief will naturally result in our open profession of faith in Him. It is a joyful outflow from our heart that springs from the peace we have with God. Our mouth and our heart act in harmony. Our mouth will sing the hymn of faith as our heart beats the rhythm. Genuine faith combined with our confession gains us the righteousness of the Son and reconciliation with the Father so we have eternal salvation.

Confession is not made once only at our conversion. We confess our faith each time we gather with like-minded Christians for corporate worship. At baptism, we publicly identify ourselves as children of God. We are recipients of the covenant of grace, in-grafted into Christ by the regeneration of the heart and remission of sins, and commit ourselves to walk in newness of life (Westminster Confession of Faith). Partaking the Lord's Supper reminds us of the sacrifice our Lord Jesus made for the forgiveness of our sins. Together, the two sacraments, Holy Baptism and the Lord's Supper, visually express the whole Gospel. Evangelism is another means of confessing our faith to others. May God help us to boldly profess our faith and the good news of salvation to all we meet so they may be saved from their sins.
26 JULY.part7: And said unto them, Thus it is written, and thus it behoved Christ to suffer, and to rise from the dead the third day: And that repentance and remission of sins should be preached in his name among all nations, beginning at Jerusalem. - Luke 24:46-47

27 JULY.part4: For the scripture saith, Whosoever believeth on him shall not be ashamed.
27 JULY.part5:
As Christians, we often face ridicule and shame for our faith. The apostle Paul quotes Isaiah 28:16 to reassure Christians that we will not be ashamed when we place our trust in our Lord Jesus to save. The biblical meaning of not being ashamed has many facets.

Firstly, we will not be disappointed or let down by our faith in Jesus Christ. In Romans 5, Paul tells us we have been justified by faith and have peace with God through our Lord Jesus who died for us while we were yet sinners. Our hope and faith in Jesus will not let us down. We will be saved as God promised in His Word.

Secondly, we will not suffer shame before the Lord God on the Day of Judgement. We can appear boldly because we have no fear of our sins being exposed before Him [1 John 2:28]. Our sins have been washed away and our slate is wiped clean because of the atoning work of Christ. We are now clothed in robes of righteousness by God's grace.

Lastly, those who place their trust in riches, achievements and connections to save themselves may mock and pour scorn on the children of God, but we need not be cowed or intimidated. When they appear before God in judgement, all earthly things count for nothing. They will be confounded and left speechless as their spiritual nakedness is exposed. They will have no excuse for their sin and rejection of the Saviour. In shame and humiliation, they will be condemned without hope for redemption. May God use us to bring them the Gospel before it is too late.
27 JULY.part7: Wherefore also it is contained in the scripture, Behold, I lay in Sion a chief corner stone, elect, precious: and he that believeth on him shall not be confounded. - 1 Peter 2:6

28 JULY.part4: For there is no difference between the Jew and the Greek: for the same Lord over all is rich unto all that call upon him.
28 JULY.part5:
The good news about the Gospel of salvation is that it is open to everyone. All are invited without exception to come to our Lord Jesus for salvation. No one is excluded. God does not favour any group of people in salvation either. There is no difference among any of us before God. Neither cultural heritage nor family upbringing confer any advantage for the following reasons.

Firstly, all of us are sinners who have fallen short of God's holy standard [Romans 3:23]. None of us can do anything of our own accord to have a right relationship with God. Everyone is equally sinful and equally deserving of His wrath and punishment.

Secondly, our Lord is the same Lord over all people. He is not different towards different people applying different rules for them. There is only one way of salvation - through Jesus Christ who died for the sins of all mankind. All must come to the Father through the blood of the Son [John 14:6]. Conversely, all who do not believe in Jesus to save will suffer the same condemnation [John 3:18].

Lastly, our Lord Jesus is rich toward all that call upon Him. God is infinitely rich in love, mercy and grace, and desires to bestow these abundantly upon us. God's generosity is not reserved for some but offered to all who believe. We thank God no matter how great the multitude that calls upon our Lord for salvation, all have the same promise of blessing. His wealth of saving grace is never exhausted and He never wearies of bestowing it upon us.
28 JULY.part7: For there is one God, and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus. - 1 Timothy 2:5

29 JULY.part4: For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.
29 JULY.part5:
Paul was writing to the church at Rome, and his desire was that they might be saved. He had stated in the previous verse that "there is no difference between the Jew and the Greek: for the same Lord over all is rich unto all that call upon him" [v. 12]. He had also said that the Jews had "a zeal of God, but not according to knowledge" [v. 2]. That meant that their knowledge of God was defective. The Gentiles, on the other hand, were very much influenced by the Graeco-Roman religions and myths. Their knowledge was deficient.

So, who is this Lord of salvation who is rich unto all that call upon Him?

First, He is known by several names. His name is Jesus, which means "Jehovah Saves" or "the Lord is Salvation" [Matthew 1:21]. This name appears in the first verse [Matthew 1:1] and the last verse [Revelation 22:21] of the New Testament. That is the Name upon whom we call if we want to be saved. He is "the mighty God ... the Prince of Peace" [Isaiah 9:6]. He is Immanuel [Isaiah 7:14; Matthew 1:23]. He is the Christ - the promised anointed Messiah - the One to whom the prophets give witness.

Second, He is known for what He came to do. The angels announced to Joseph that his betrothed wife would bear a Son, and "he shall save his people from their sins" [Matthew 1:21]. Jesus came to be our substitute. He is our vicarious atonement.

Third, He is known for His authority. He taught "as one having authority, and not as the scribes" [Matthew 7:29]. And His Name became our authority in the preaching of the Gospel [Luke 24:47]. The name of Jesus Christ was Paul's message [1 Corinthians 2:2; 9:16]. And it should be ours as well.
29 JULY.part7: The doctrine is not our message; Christ is.

30 JULY.part4: For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.
30 JULY.part5:
The Gospel of Jesus Christ transcends all barriers - national, racial, linguistic, cultural, gender, and socio-economic. "For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved."

The word "whosoever" simply means "all" (Greek: pas). The exact connotation of pas depends upon the context of the passage. Pas with a definite article and a participle has the idea of "everyone who, whoever" as in John 3:16, "whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life."

"Whosoever" is as broad a category as one can imagine. That is the scope of God's salvation plan. That is what our Lord has done in His will. In this covenant of grace - the final and "better testament" [Hebrews 7:22] - God has not identified nationalities. He has not identified personalities. Instead, He used one word that covers the whole world, the whole gamut of humanity - whosoever. It does not matter if you are the richest man in the world or the poorest. It does not matter if you are black or white or brown. It does not matter if you are old or young, if you are ninety or nine, learned or illiterate, bond or free, Jew or Gentile, male or female. All are covered by "whosoever".

That is the glory of the Gospel. The blood of Jesus Christ is shed for and cleanses every sin of every sinner. If you are a believer, you are saved not because of who you are or what you have done, but because God has included you under His "whosoever". If you have not believed, you can be saved too, if you will only humble yourself and call upon the Lord Jesus Christ in faith.
30 JULY.part7: The elect of God is the "whosoever" of God.

31 JULY.part4: For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.
31 JULY.part5:
To "call upon the name" of a person has several connotations. First, it is "to invoke" that person's authority. The apostle Peter in his first sermon quoted Joel, "it shall come to pass, that whosoever shall call on the name of the Lord shall be saved" [Acts 2:21; Joel 2:32]. As the enemies stoned Stephen, he called upon God [Acts 7:59]. In these two instances, it is synonymous with "praying".

"To call upon the name of the Lord" also has the technical and classical meaning of summoning a witness. In 2 Corinthians 1:23, Paul wrote that he called "God for a record upon my soul", appealing to God to witness his actions on behalf of the Corinthians.

Third, to call upon the name of the Lord is to be identified with Him. In the Old Testament, to call upon the name of the LORD signifies a relationship with God - "If my people, which are called by my name ... " [2 Chronicles 7:14; see also Deuteronomy 28:10; Isaiah 43:7; Amos 9:12].

In the New Testament, Luke describes followers of Jesus as those who "call upon" the name of the Lord [Acts 9:14, 21; 15:17]. The apostle Paul also associated those calling upon the name of the Lord Jesus Christ with the Church, affirming the deity of our Lord Jesus. Clearly, He is the "name of the Lord" to whom believers must turn.

Peter, at the moment he was sinking in the water, called on the Lord [Matthew 14:30]. The leper called on the Lord [Luke 5:12]. The thief on the cross called on the Lord [Luke 23:42]. And He heard them. What a privilege and blessing it is for us to be in such company as those who call upon the name of the Lord.
31 JULY.part7: God's desire is that we who are "called to be saints ... call upon the name of Jesus Christ our Lord" [1 Corinthians 1:2]

1 AUGUST.part4: For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.
1 AUGUST.part5:
Romans 10:13 is not to be taken as some form of paganistic incantation or heathen superstition. The Bible is clear that sincere faith is of the essence because "without faith it is impossible to please him: for he that cometh to God must believe that he is, and that he is a rewarder of them that diligently seek him" [Hebrews 11:6].

Believing with less than a full heart is as bad as an unbelieving heart. God would not want to have anything to do with a wavering heart. James writes: "If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, that giveth to all men liberally, and upbraideth not; and it shall be given him. But let him ask in faith, nothing wavering. For he that wavereth is like a wave of the sea driven with the wind and tossed. For let not that man think that he shall receive any thing of the Lord" [James 1:5-7].

God is also not pleased with a divided heart. Our Lord Jesus says, "No man can serve two masters" [Matthew 6:24a]. He is going to hate one and love the other. He is going to cling to the one and despise the other." It is impossible to love and serve two masters! Our minds must be made up.

God also does not want anything to do with a proud and insincere heart. Instead, God looks for a broken and contrite heart. "A broken and a contrite heart, O God, thou wilt not despise" [Psalm 51:17]. The God of the universe - the high and lofty One that inhabiteth eternity, whose name is Holy ... (He will dwell) with him also that is of a contrite and humble spirit, to revive the spirit of the humble, and to revive the heart of the contrite ones" [Isaiah 57:15].
1 AUGUST.part7: Ye shall seek me, and find me, when ye shall search for me with all your heart. - Jeremiah 29:13

2 AUGUST.part4: For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.
2 AUGUST.part5:
To call on the name of the Lord is not restricted to an audible call. Hannah called upon God, but "she spake in her heart; only her lips moved, but her voice was not heard" [1 Samuel 1:13]. Hers was a silent call. Mark records a woman sick for twelve years, who had heard of our Lord Jesus, and she said, "If I may touch but his clothes, I shall be whole" [Mark 5:25-28]. Hers too was a silent call.

You can call without saying a word. You can call on the Lord also by simply looking. That was what happened in the wilderness when the LORD instructed Moses to make "a fiery serpent, and set it upon a pole ... (so) that every one that is bitten, when he looketh upon it, shall live" [Numbers 21:8]. God also called on the people, "Look unto me, and be ye saved" [Isaiah 45:22a].

You can call on the Lord even without looking. You can call on the Lord just by directing your thoughts toward Him because God knows our hearts; He looks on the heart, especially the broken heart.

The Pharisee in his religious garb and outward show of piety went to the temple, and "prayed thus with himself, God, I thank thee, that I am not as other men are, extortioners, unjust, adulterers, or even as this publican" [Luke 18:11]. The publican, on the other hand, "would not lift up so much as his eyes unto heaven, but smote upon his breast, saying, God be merciful to me a sinner" [Luke 18:13], and went away justified.

So, call on the Lord where you are and in whatever way you can because it is not your eloquence that brings God to your prayers, but your brokenness.
2 AUGUST.part7: Seek ye the LORD while he may be found, call ye upon him while he is near. - Isaiah 55:6

3 AUGUST.part4: For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.
3 AUGUST.part5:
We can call on the Lord by looking on Him, reaching out to Him, or even by thinking and desiring salvation. When we begin to realize our utter depravity and desperate inability and turn to the grace and compassion of our Lord Jesus, we will be saved!

There is no better illustration of desperation than that of a drowning man. When the man is flailing his arms, grasping the air trying to keep himself afloat and screaming, "save me", we can be sure his calls for deliverance are real.

Salvation is by calling on the "name of the Lord". Now a sinner may miss salvation by calling on the wrong name, on the wrong Saviour, or the wrong Lord. And Paul reminds us that "whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved". This is important because "there is one God, and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus," and "there is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved" [1 Timothy 2:5; Acts 4:12].

With the name of the Lord comes also the surety of salvation. "Whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved." After the children of Israel had defeated the Philistines, Samuel erected a stone and called it Ebenezer [1 Samuel 7:12]. The hymn-writer, Robert Robinson appropriated the phrase in a stanza of his hymn Count Thou Fount - "Here I raise my Ebenezer" - to remind Christians of their need to rely on the Lord, and the certainty of His deliverance. What a comfort for us to know that there are no ifs and maybes in God's promises, but only shall and will.
3 AUGUST.part7: For all the promises of God in (Christ) are yea, and in him Amen, unto the glory of God by us. - 2 Corinthians 1:20

4 AUGUST.part4: How then shall they call on him in whom they have not believed? and shall they believe in him of whom they have not heard? and how shall they hear without a preacher?
4 AUGUST.part5:
In his epistle to the Romans, Paul describes the predicament of persons apart from Christ. They are unrighteous, self-seeking not God-seeking, practising evil in word and deed, and living without a conscious fear of God; they are totally unworthy of His grace and salvation [Romans 3:9-20]. How then are they to be saved? "For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved. How then shall they call on him in whom they have not believed?" [v. 13-14]. For them to call, they must believe, and they cannot believe if they have not heard; therefore, someone must tell them the Gospel.

Believing in Christ is not simply accepting the historic facts of His life. Believing in Christ means committing ourselves to Him, venturing our life here and in eternity upon Him. It means surrendering ourselves to Him so that He can shape and mould us. It is believing in obedience, for where there is obedience, there is faith.

In Romans 10:9-10, Paul ties belief in Christ's resurrection directly to our salvation experience. "That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved. For with the heart man believeth unto righteousness; and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation." The encouragement here given is that anyone, Jew or Gentile, trusting in Him, will never be put to shame, but saved. As the saying goes, "If anyone is saved, it is because God does all the saving."
4 AUGUST.part7: For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast. - Ephesians 2:8-9

5 AUGUST.part4: How then shall they call on him in whom they have not believed? and shall they believe in him of whom they have not heard? and how shall they hear without a preacher?
5 AUGUST.part5:
In Romans 9:1-29, apostle Paul gives an exposition of God's sovereign grace in Israel's past election. In Romans 9:30-10:21, he describes the nation's present rejection of the Lord and their need for the Gospel. Paul's heart's desire and prayer to God for Israel is that they will be saved [v. 1]. The Jews were zealous but lacked the knowledge of true salvation outlined in Romans 3:21-26. They refused to embrace salvation through Christ as Simeon had done [Luke 2:28-32]. Israel's hardened condition resulted in a national rejection of the Messiah who was "the end (completion or perfection) of the law for righteousness to every one that believeth" [v. 4]. The Jews had stumbled over this stumbling stone who alone could make right their "faulty" righteousness of works [Romans 9:31-32]. While God is responsible for the salvation of any Jew who comes to faith as evidenced in chapter 9, Romans 10 explains that the Jews themselves are responsible for their own rejection of the Saviour.

In Romans 10:12 Paul explains that in Christ "there is no difference between the Jew and the Greek: for the same Lord over all is rich unto all that call upon him." The Gentiles obtained righteousness by faith in Christ and not by lawkeeping. Since faith is the necessary component for one's salvation, the lost must receive this message that accurately proclaims the Gospel of Christ. While ethnic Israel was in a state of hardened rejection, the Lord is still willing to save both sinful Jews and Gentiles as they hear this message of salvation preached.
5 AUGUST.part7: Election is the eternal act of God with respect to all who are saved, by which, out of pure grace and for Christ's sake He purposed to endow them in time with a spiritual blessing of conversion, justification, sanctification and preservation unto eternal life. - R.D Culver

6 AUGUST.part4: How then shall they call on him in whom they have not believed? and shall they believe in him of whom they have not heard? and how shall they hear without a preacher?
6 AUGUST.part5:
To Paul, the Gospel centred on Jesus Christ alone and what God has done through Him. In Christ are the essentials of the Gospel - His virgin birth, His divinity as the Son of God, His humility and death on the cross for our sins, His burial, resurrection, and future coming as the King in judgment. To Paul, Christ is the Gospel. In Romans 10, Paul urges the necessity of preaching this so people may be saved.

When Paul preached to the Athenians in Acts 17:16-33, many mocked the doctrine of Jesus' resurrection [Acts 17:32]. This was also the case with the Corinthian Christians. Not many were saved by Paul's preaching. Yet "faith cometh by hearing and hearing by the word of God" [v. 17]. The Gospel is for all to hear.

As in time past, many today reject God's Word. When we share the Gospel with anyone, we will receive several predictable responses depending on the condition of the hearer's heart. Some will refuse, oppose and reject the message. Some will receive it with short-lived enthusiasm. When difficulty arises, they drift away. Their response and faith prove superficial. Some are attracted to the Gospel, but their hearts are still occupied with things of the world. They are unwilling to commit fully to Christ. But, when God's Word is shared with one who is truly seeking, they will believe; the Holy Spirit convicts them and brings them to a wondrous salvation in the Lord Jesus. They accept with their heart the person and work of Christ for them personally and repent of their sins. Therefore, we must be faithful in sharing and sowing the Gospel message wherever we are to whoever we meet, whenever we can.
6 AUGUST.part7: And he said unto them, Go ye into all the world and preach the gospel to every creature. - Mark 16:15

7 AUGUST.part4: And how shall they preach, except they be sent? as it is written, How beautiful are the feet of them that preach the gospel of peace, and bring glad tidings of good things!
7 AUGUST.part5:
Being able to preach the Gospel is a blessing from God. Afterall, who are we to be given this privilege of conveying God's great salvation plan, and handling things that have eternal impact on people's souls? Finite creatures like us can only understand God's will through what He has revealed to us, and having tasted His goodness, we can bring forth God's blessings to the people around us.

Being sent to herald God's message to a fallen world is also God's blessing. "Sent" here in Greek is apostalosin which comes from the word apostello, from which we get the noun apostolos or "apostle." There are at least two senses to the word "apostle": it could refer specifically to Jesus' twelve chosen disciples who have seen the resurrected Christ, or it could simply mean a messenger who is sent forth to preach God's Word. We may not be messengers of the Gospel formally sent by the church, but all of us are told to go forth into the world to shine for Him.

Being able to receive the true Gospel from a faithful preacher and teacher of God's Word is definitely a blessing from God too. If only every Christian aspires to be a good testimony of the manifold grace of God, and proclaim the Word especially through a life that is consistent to his faith, then consciences will be pricked, hearts made soft and teachable, and lost souls will be saved.

Indeed, salvation is only of the Lord, but God has chosen to work through us to extend His kingdom, that we might in blessing others, be blessed as well.
7 AUGUST.part7: Give, and it shall be given unto you; good measure, pressed down, and shaken together, and running over, shall men give into your bosom. For with the same measure that ye mete withal it shall be measured to you again. - Luke 6:38

8 AUGUST.part4: And how shall they preach, except they be sent? as it is written, How beautiful are the feet of them that preach the gospel of peace, and bring glad tidings of good things!
8 AUGUST.part5:
Paul next quoted from Isaiah 52:7: "How beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace; that bringeth good tidings of good, that publisheth salvation; that saith unto Zion, Thy God reigneth!" These descriptions give us a vivid portrait of a person bringing the message everywhere he goes, even to the uttermost parts of the world. He brings peace and gladness of good things. The feet of such a person are beautiful.

We bring to the world a Gospel of peace. It is only through our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ that we have peace with God. We are reconciled to God through the blood of Christ, and because of that we can have peace within ourselves - something which the world searches frantically for but to no avail, simply because they are looking in the wrong places. Only the Gospel enables us to have peace with God and have the peace of God. And with that peace, we can have peace with others, as well as with the rest of creation.

We also need to tell others about the glad tidings of good things. "Good things" not in terms of what the world deems good, but rather the spiritual blessings that accompany the grace and knowledge of our Lord Jesus.

"As it is written" tells us this is indeed God's beautiful plan from the beginning to the end. The Old Testament and New Testament bear consistent testimony of God's gracious dealings with us, simply because God is the ultimate author of the holy Word. Thank God for His wonderful blessings, and may our feet be beautiful carriers of God's gift to this lost world.
8 AUGUST.part7: What shall we then say to these things? If God be for us, who can be against us? He that spared not his own Son, but delivered him up for us all, how shall he not with him also freely give us all things? - Romans 8:31-32

9 AUGUST.part4: But they have not all obeyed the gospel. For Esaias saith, Lord, who hath believed our report?
9 AUGUST.part5:
We see how Paul cited Isaiah 52:7 in the previous verse. He now names Isaiah ("Esaias") specifically, showing us that, whether in the days of old or our day, there are always people who will not believe the testimonies of God's messengers and refuse to obey the Gospel. The sinful nature runs in all men through all times.

The Gospel is clearly spelt out in God's Word. To be saved, we must confess we are sinners and come to the Lord through His only begotten Son. The Old Testament points toward this truth, and in the New Testament, it was made clear with the coming of our Lord Jesus. Our Lord had proclaimed, "I am the Way, the Truth, and the Life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by Me." Jesus Christ is the only way to be saved from condemnation.

Sadly, there are people who do not take this command of God seriously. Some consider it as an offer, as if God is cordially inviting us to trust in Christ as a way, with Christ being only one of several choices we can have in order to be saved. This is especially so in a consumer-oriented society like ours. With so much information and choices at hand (and in our handphones), the Gospel is seen as one option among many "truths".

Yet God's absolute Word tells us differently. The almighty God in heaven because of His love, came down and died for our sins. What should our response be? It is foolish of us to take the Gospel light-heartedly, or delay like the "wise" men of Athens, saying, "We will hear thee again of this matter." [Acts 17:32b]
9 AUGUST.part7: And this is his commandment, That we should believe on the name of his Son Jesus Christ, and love one another, as he gave us commandment. - 1 John 3:23

10 AUGUST.part4: But they have not all obeyed the gospel. For Esaias saith, Lord, who hath believed our report?
10 AUGUST.part5:
The command to obedience is found throughout the Bible. The reason for the Israelites' wandering in the wilderness was disobedience. The reason why they could not settle peacefully in Canaan is because they did not obey God's command to conquer the land completely. They did things according to what they thought was correct in their own eyes. Disobedience to God's command also resulted in their 70 years of exile in a foreign land. Yet such is the tendency of fallen man.

Our sinful nature desires independence and selfautonomy, not realizing that a life out of sync with the will of God is filled with regrets and sorrows. Even when the Son of God came into this world to show us the Gospel which the Old Testament pointed to, there are still many who choose not to believe. There are two reasons why this is so. The first is lust. They are not willing to give up their sinful beliefs and lifestyles. To these people, our Lord Jesus said, "No man can serve two masters: for either he will hate the one, and love the other; or else he will hold to the one, and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon." [Matthew 6:24]

A second reason for disobedience is pride. We want things to be done our way instead of God's way. Man, including many believers, are so blinded by their projects of wood, hay and stubble, they forget that one day all these works of vanity will not endure the judgment of fire. To these people, our Lord Jesus said, "If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me." [Matthew 16:24]
10 AUGUST.part7: For all that is in the world, the lust of the flesh, and the lust of the eyes, and the pride of life, is not of the Father, but is of the world. And the world passeth away, and the lust thereof: but he that doeth the will of God abideth for ever. - 1 John 2:16-17

11 AUGUST.part4: But they have not all obeyed the gospel. For Esaias saith, Lord, who hath believed our report?
11 AUGUST.part5:
The Messiah came to this world some 2,000 years ago, yet who would know the purpose, and expect the manner in which He came? The Israelites were praying for their Messiah to come as a mighty king to save them from their neighbouring enemies, yet they did not realise they were in a more dangerous state spiritually. The Saviour came not to save mankind from their physical predicament; He came to save us from our eternal condemnation.

It is with this understanding that Paul quoted Isaiah 53:1, for the whole chapter of Isaiah 53 is about how Christ came into our world as a suffering servant, "despised and rejected of men; a man of sorrows, and acquainted with grief " [Isaiah 53:3]. "He was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our iniquities: the chastisement of our peace was upon him; and with his stripes we are healed." [Isaiah 53:5]

Yet it is precisely in this manner the Son of God would accomplish His Father's salvation plan. It was totally contrary to what human wisdom would suggest. As the Lord walked closer and closer to the cross, one could perhaps even imagine Satan thinking he had succeeded. Yet the moment our Lord Jesus died, the work was finished. The thick curtain in the Temple separating man from God was torn into two from the top to the bottom. Three days later, He rose again, showing that He is indeed God the Son, giving us the assurance of our own resurrection and everlasting life.

Indeed, "the Jews require a sign, and the Greeks seek after wisdom: But we preach Christ crucified, unto the Jews a stumblingblock, and unto the Greeks foolishness; But unto them which are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ the power of God, and the wisdom of God." [1 Corinthians 1:22-24]
11 AUGUST.part7: Amazing love! How can it be? That Thou, my God, should die for me? - Charles Wesley

12 AUGUST.part4: So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God.
12 AUGUST.part5:
Where does faith originate? What is the source of faith? From Romans 10:17, it would seem that faith is the product of hearing the preaching of the Gospel. We know that is not always the case. There are people who have heard the Gospel preached and yet remained unbelieving. When Paul says, "faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God", he is not saying that all who hear will definitely come to faith in Christ.

What Paul meant by those words is that a person cannot come to faith in Christ unless there is the preaching of the Gospel. Faith does not come by any means other than the Word preached. That is why Cyprian of Carthage - the third-century church father - said "extra ecclesiam nulla salus," which is Latin for "outside the church, there is no salvation," meaning that outside of the church, there is no possibility of hearing the Gospel.

For Paul, faith is the voice that speaks the message heard in the heart, a message that will be confirmed by the Gospel when a person hears it preached. There are those who hold the view that it is the manner in which a person hears and responds to the audible message of the Gospel that produces faith.

The two ideas are quite different. In one case the onus of belief resides in the man who preaches and the person who hears. In the other, it is the divine work of grace that instills faith in the heart. The first view challenges the unregenerate sinner, "If you will have faith, God will save you." The other view, Paul's view, informs the regenerate sinner, "God has saved you, and through your hearing the Gospel engenders faith in you."
