12 AUGUST.part7: "When the Son of man cometh, shall he find faith on the earth?" [Luke 18:8b]. Most assuredly, Christ will find faith where He has worked!

13 AUGUST.part4: So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God.
13 AUGUST.part5:
"Faith cometh by hearing" -- That is the universal testimony of Holy Scripture. Sinners are saved by the grace of God, through the merits of Christ's precious blood, and the mighty operation of God the Holy Ghost, through the instrumentality of Gospel preaching.

The preaching and the hearing of the Gospel are essential to the salvation of souls. God is absolutely sovereign not only in the subjects of salvation, but also in the means of salvation. The Lord our God is sovereign. He saves His people altogether by grace, without any works of their own.

That does not mean it is not necessary to preach or hear the Gospel. There are some who take "Salvation is of the LORD" [Jonah 2:9b] to mean it is not necessary to preach or hear the Gospel; that there is no need for sinners to repent.

The Bible teaches otherwise. Our Lord Jesus says, "He that heareth my word, and believeth on him that sent me, hath everlasting life" [John 5:24]. There is also a consistent apostolic affirmation of the preaching of the Gospel for salvation. The apostle Paul says "I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation" [Romans 1:16]. He told the Corinthians that God willed it to use "the foolishness of preaching to save them that believe" [1 Corinthians 1:21]. James says that God has begotten us "with the word of truth [James 1:18]. Peter says that we are "born again ... by the word of God, which liveth and abideth for ever ... And this is the word which by the gospel is preached unto you" [1 Peter 1:23-25].

The simple truth is this - no preaching of the Gospel, no presentation of faith and no pleasing of God [Hebrews 11:6], thus no possibility of salvation. Pray for the preaching as well as hearing of the Gospel.
13 AUGUST.part7: Pray for faith to believe and to receive the Word of God with meekness and joy.

14 AUGUST.part4: So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God.
14 AUGUST.part5:
Paul writes: "The invisible things of him from the creation of the world are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made, even his eternal power and Godhead; so that they are without excuse" [Romans 1:20]. In pre-evangelism apologetics, the question most frequently asked is this - If faith comes by hearing, what about those who have not heard?

There are two main schools of thought. There are those who hold the view that the believer is responsible to make the first step; he must create faith in the individual by his preaching, and then motivate the individual to take "saving" steps toward God. The second view holds that God must first perform the work of grace in the sinner's heart or else all human efforts will be futile. Then there is also the blending of the two - the first work of grace comes from God and yet at the same time the believer must present the Gospel, which the Holy Spirit will use to bring the unbeliever to a state of faith.

In any case, it is clear that faith never builds on a vacuum of knowledge. It builds on credible evidence for a certain belief. The question is: where does the evidence on which faith rests originate? Does it originate in the message we preach? Or does it originate with God's saving grace planted in the heart generating the voice which speaks within?

Saving faith is based on the enlightening grace of God which He sovereignly bestows in regeneration. It builds on the foundational premise that our knowledge of God and our response to Him grow out of His first act of grace in saving us and bestowing His nature upon us in regeneration.
14 AUGUST.part7: Meditate upon these things; give thyself wholly to them; that thy profiting may appear to all. Take heed unto thyself, and unto the doctrine; continue in them: for in doing this thou shalt both save thyself, and them that hear thee. - 1 Timothy 4:1516

15 AUGUST.part4: So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God.
15 AUGUST.part5:
When we read the Word of God, four essential truths stand out.

First, there is only one Gospel. It is the Gospel of God concerning His Son, testifying that Jesus is the Christ. This is the Gospel that Paul and the apostles preached. This is the Gospel that we in the 21st century must continue to preach - "that Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures" [1 Corinthians 15:1-3].

Second, no one can be saved without hearing the Gospel. God could have chosen to send angels to reveal His saving grace. God could, if He chose, take his elect to heaven without ever sending a preacher. Rather, in His infinite and wise sovereignty, He ordained that the preaching of the Gospel would be the means by which salvation would be made known. "It pleased God by the foolishness of preaching to save them that believe" [1 Corinthians 1:21].

Third, no one will ever be saved without believing the Christ. "He that believeth on the Son hath everlasting life: and he that believeth not the Son shall not see life; but the wrath of God abideth on him" [John 3:36]. Faith in Christ is indispensable to salvation. Whoever believes is God's elect. Whoever is the elect believes.

Fourth, no sinner will ever be saved without the repentance of sin. Our Lord Jesus said, "Except ye repent, ye shall all likewise perish" [Luke 13:3]. The gate of faith into salvation is also the gate of repentance. Peter writes that the Lord "is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance" [2 Peter 3:9b]. Repentance is turning to God. Repentance is a change of heart and mind. Repentance is a change of one's allegiance.
15 AUGUST.part7: The road of salvation begins at a fork - repent or perish!

16 AUGUST.part4: So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God.
16 AUGUST.part5:
When the children of Israel were wandering in the wilderness, they saw the visible manifestation of God daily - the pillar of cloud by day and the pillar of fire by night. Then, forty years later, as they were about to enter the Promised Land, Moses warned them about what they would see and against following the ways of the Canaanites. Moses emphasized the importance of hearing God's Word.

"Now therefore hearken, O Israel, unto the statutes and unto the judgments, which I teach you, for to do them ..." [Deuteronomy 4:1]. "Gather me the people together, and I will make them hear my words, that they may learn to fear me all the days that they shall live upon the earth, and that they may teach their children" [Deuteronomy 4:10]. "Take ye therefore good heed unto yourselves; for ye saw no manner of similitude on the day that the LORD spake unto you in Horeb out of the midst of the fire: Lest ye corrupt yourselves, and make you a graven image" [Deuteronomy 4:15-16; see also 23-24, 33, 36, 40].

Why the emphasis on hearing rather than seeing? The reason is that our sense of sight often betrays us. Eve "saw that the tree was good for food, and that it was pleasant to the eyes ..." [Genesis 3:6], and she ate of the forbidden fruit. Achan saw the spoils, and he coveted and took the forbidden loot [Joshua 7:21]. David saw Bathsheba washing herself; he coveted her and committed adultery [2 Samuel 11:2]. The eye seems to be the organ most susceptible to sin, and idolatry exploits man's weakness of the sense of sight.

That is why the Gospel presents our Saviour as the Good Shepherd whose "sheep hear (His) voice ... and they follow (Him)" [John 10:27].
16 AUGUST.part7: The look of faith to God comes by way of the hearing of His Word.

17 AUGUST.part4: So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God.
17 AUGUST.part5:
In the parable of the soils [Luke 8:5-18], our Lord Jesus speaks of how the Word of God is received by different types of hearers. Some heard the Word but immediately dismissed it. Others heard but the Word failed to take root in their hearts or they were distracted by the cares of this world. Then, there are others who "having heard the word, keep it, and bring forth fruit with patience" [Luke 8:15].

In that parable, our Lord Jesus tells us that the multitudes came out of every city to hear Him, but there are many who did not receive any saving benefit from the preaching of the Gospel. So, in verse 18, our Lord Jesus gave this application, "Take heed therefore how ye hear" [Luke 8:18]. If we would profit spiritually and eternally from the preaching of the Gospel, we must take heed how we hear.

How then should we hear?

Prepare your heart. Hearing starts with the heart. Whenever you come into God's house, prepare your heart with an intense desire to hear His Word. "If we were as swift to hear as we are ready to speak there would be ... more profit in our meetings." (Thomas Manton)

Seize every opportunity to hear the Word of God. Be careful that nothing chokes out the influence of the Gospel in our lives. Be like David whose one desire was to "dwell in the house of the LORD all the days of (his) life, to behold the beauty of the LORD, and to enquire in his temple" [Psalm 27:4]. Be like Mary who "sat at Jesus' feet, and heard his word" [Luke 10:39].

Make certain that in hearing, you hear the Gospel. Discern what you hear. Beware of another Gospel.
17 AUGUST.part7: The responsibility of preaching the Gospel rests on the shoulders of the man in the pulpit. The responsibility of hearing the Gospel rests on the shoulders of the people in the pews. So hear, and hear well!

18 AUGUST.part4: So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God.
18 AUGUST.part5:
Our Lord Jesus, quoting from Isaiah's prophecy, speaks of those who hear but shall not understand. The reason is that the people's "heart is waxed gross, and their ears are dull of hearing, and their eyes they have closed" [Matthew 13:1315]. This means that it is God who gives us grace to hear and understand the Gospel.

God gives us grace to hear with attention. Paul commended the Thessalonians: "when ye received the word of God which ye heard of us, ye received it not as the word of men, but as it is in truth, the word of God, which effectually worketh also in you that believe [1 Thessalonians 2:13].

God gives us grace to hear with humility. Paul says that God uses "the foolish things of the world to confound the wise ... the weak things of the world to confound the things which are mighty" [1 Corinthians 1:26-27] so that our "faith should not stand in the wisdom of men, but in the power of God" [1 Corinthians 2:5]. Thus, we must "receive with meekness the engrafted word, which is able to save (our) souls" [James 1:21].

God gives us grace to listen with purity of heart. This means we are to listen with self-examination and introspection. Three times, the writer of Hebrews says, "To day if ye will hear his voice, harden not your hearts, as in the provocation" [Hebrews 3:7-8, 15; 4:7]. It also means that when we are convicted by God's Word, we must confess and repent of our sins.

God gives us the grace to listen with love. The Psalmist declares, "I will delight myself in thy commandments, which I have loved. My hands also will I lift up unto thy commandments, which I have loved ... O how love I thy law! It is my meditation all the day" [Psalm 119:47-48, 97].
18 AUGUST.part7: Hearing is an act of eternal consequence. According to our hearing, so shall the state of our souls be in eternity.

19 AUGUST.part4: But I say, Have they not heard? Yes verily, their sound went into all the earth, and their words unto the ends of the world.
19 AUGUST.part5:
When Paul wrote this passage, the Gospel had already been preached extensively in all the known nations. It had been proclaimed in Rome, Jerusalem, Syria, Asia Minor, Arabia and in the islands of the Mediterranean. God's message of salvation had been freely preached to all, for anyone to receive Christ as their Saviour.

But many people were still unbelieving. Apostle Paul questioned why, rhetorically asking if it was because they had not heard the Scripture for themselves. Of course not! God's creation all around them was a living testament to His greatness (quoting from Psalm 19:4).

John 12:37 reminds us that even after Jesus had performed many miracles, many of the people still would not believe in Him. Their spiritual eyes were blinded, and their hearts hardened so they could neither perceive nor understand with their hearts. In fact, through many channels today, the Gospel has been shared in every corner of the world, yet many people who have heard still refuse to believe. They are still spiritually dead in their transgressions and sins [Ephesians 2:1].

Do not be discouraged if our witnessing for Christ is rejected. Our task is to continue reaching out to unsaved souls to share the Good News. We must be prepared to preach the Gospel in season or out of season [2 Timothy 4:2], and keep praying for the Holy Spirit to touch the hearts of our loved ones who have yet to accept Christ.
19 AUGUST.part7: O Lord, I thank You for Your grace and love for us. You have called us as believers to go into the world to proclaim Your Gospel. May You grant me the courage, passion, boldness to witness for You and share my faith with others. Amen.

20 AUGUST.part4: But I say, Did not Israel know? First Moses saith, I will provoke you to jealousy by them that are no people, and by a foolish nation I will anger you.
20 AUGUST.part5:
The Israelites were God's chosen people from the beginning. Of all the nations, Israel should have been the first to understand God's message and accept Jesus as their Messiah. However, they rejected Him, just as it was described in the Old Testament. God called His people "stiffnecked people" [Deuteronomy 9:6] and Jeremiah described God's people as having "not hearkened, nor inclined your ear to hear" in Jeremiah 25:4.

Now, Paul quotes Deuteronomy 32:21 to say that God intends to save the Gentiles to provoke the Jews to jealousy. God would make the Jews envious by forging a new relationship with nations who had no previous encounters or relationship with the Almighty God. The Jews had to humble themselves and see how the Spirit of God burned more brightly in the new proselytes. Proverbs 3:3435 echoes this: "Surely he scorneth the scorners: but he giveth grace unto the lowly. The wise shall inherit glory: but shame shall be the promotion of fools."

Paul explains it well in Acts 13:46. The Gospel was first shared with the Jews but they rejected it, thus salvation was offered to the Gentiles. Have we also rejected God in our day to day lives? Do our actions toward God mirror the New Testament Jews, when we claim to love God and yet constantly spite Him and neglect our relationship with Him? Let us not throw away this precious Gift we have been given.
20 AUGUST.part7: Wherefore, my beloved, as ye have always obeyed, not as in my presence only, but now much more in my absence, work out your own salvation with fear and trembling. For it is God which worketh in you both to will and to do of his good pleasure. - Philippians 2:12-13

21 AUGUST.part4: But to Israel he saith, All day long I have stretched forth my hands unto a disobedient and gainsaying people.
21 AUGUST.part5:
In verses 20-21, Paul quotes Isaiah 65:1-2 to highlight the contrast between the Jews and the Gentiles in their response to the Gospel. The Gentiles did not seek God but found Him. The Jews, to whom God had continually reached out with the way of salvation, rejected Him. An even greater contrast is found within verse 21 - the contrast between the compassion and longsuffering of God who continually stretches out His hands to sinners, and the hardness of those who stubbornly turn their backs on Him.

God's love is filled with compassion and longsuffering. We are but helpless condemned sinners, completely unable to save ourselves. In His great love and mercy, He reached out to us, freely offering the gift of salvation in Christ. Even when we obstinately resist His love and rebel against His commands, God does not withdraw His love. He continues to stretch out His hands, calling us to repentance and faith in Christ.

How have you responded to God's love in Christ? Have you come to Jesus Christ as your Saviour or are you still resisting Him? If you are a Christian, do not presume upon your salvation but "give diligence to make your calling and election sure" [2 Peter 1:10]. There are many selfprofessing Christians who treat church attendance lightly, do not study the Bible and are uninterested in the things of God. Let us examine our hearts to see where we truly stand and follow our Lord in obedient discipleship.
21 AUGUST.part7: The Lord is not slack concerning his promise, as some men count slackness; but is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance. - 2 Peter 3:9

22 AUGUST.part4: I say then, Hath God cast away his people? God forbid. For I also am an Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.
22 AUGUST.part5:
In chapter 10, Paul establishes the responsibility of Israel in her rejection of Christ. Israel's unbelief is not due to a lack of hearing or understanding of the Gospel, but due to her obstinacy and disobedience. Nonetheless, God who is full of compassion and longsuffering continues to stretch out His arms toward Israel, inviting her to come to Him in repentance and faith in Christ.

As a result of Israel's rejection, the Gospel was brought to the Gentiles, many of whom readily received and were saved. Paul anticipates what his readers will ask next. Does this mean that God has rejected Israel? Has His purpose toward Israel failed? In chapter 11, Paul addresses these concerns and reveals God's plans for Israel. God has not cast away His people. He is faithful to His covenant. Israel's stumbling is in accordance with God's sovereign purpose. Her blindness will come to an end, and Israel will be restored to her place of privilege in the future. Ultimately, God has allowed all mankind to be imprisoned in disobedience so that He can reveal His mercy to all who trust in Him.

Through God's dealings with Israel in the past, present, and then in the future, we catch a glimpse of the heart and mind of our great and infinite God. Although our finite minds cannot grasp the fullness of God's sovereign plan, we know we can trust Him in His goodness, wisdom, faithfulness, and mercies. To God be all honour, glory, and praise.
22 AUGUST.part7: For the LORD is good; his mercy is everlasting; and his truth endureth to all generations. - Psalm 100:5

23 AUGUST.part4: I say then, Hath God cast away his people? God forbid. For I also am an Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.
23 AUGUST.part5:
In Romans chapters 9-11, Paul affirms God's election of Israel as a nation by referring to the nation of Israel as God's people. Israel as a whole has wilfully rejected the Gospel. It seems as if God's purpose towards Israel, His very own people, has failed, but Paul emphatically rejects any such conclusion. In what sense, then, can Israel remain as the people of God? Or does Paul have in view two Israels?

Earlier in Romans 9:6, Paul qualifies that "not all Israel ... are of Israel". There is "an Israel within Israel", a remnant who has believed the Gospel and become part of "spiritual Israel" by faith. Some theologians see "spiritual Israel" as the entire body of believers. They teach that the promises of God to Israel are not fulfilled in Israel as a nation but are fulfilled in both the Jews and the Gentiles as one people of God.

In the context of Romans 11:1 however, Paul is referring to national Israel and not spiritual Israel. Strictly speaking, only the elect, individuals chosen by God's grace, are true members of God's people. Although the corporate election of Israel does not provide for salvation in and of itself, it plays an important role in God's sovereign plan to bring about the future salvation of the Jews, as Paul will later show. Similarly, being born into a Christian home does not guarantee salvation but brings spiritual blessings to the child. The question then is - Do you treasure your spiritual privileges and use every opportunity to cultivate genuine spiritual fellowship with God?
23 AUGUST.part7: And that from a child thou hast known the holy scriptures, which are able to make thee wise unto salvation through faith which is in Christ Jesus. - 2 Timothy 3:15

24 AUGUST.part4: I say then, Hath God cast away his people? God forbid. For I also am an Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.
24 AUGUST.part5:
Romans 11 teaches that God is not done with the nation of Israel and will restore Israel someday. Many theologians, however, reject this literal interpretation, taking the view that God's promises to Israel will be fulfilled in a spiritual Israel and not national Israel. Others argue that God has rejected Israel and replaced it with the church, the new Israel. Martin Luther even wrote a pamphlet to denounce the Jews urging their persecution. The course of history - with the fall of the Jewish nation in AD 70, the diaspora, and the growth of antisemitism - seems to support the view that God has abandoned Israel. Nevertheless, by God's providence, ethnic Jews around the world continue to survive, thrive and preserve their cultural and religious identity to this day.

A genocide of the Jews known as the Holocaust, however, marks a turning point in Jewish history. The murder of nearly six million Jews by the Nazis during the Second World War led many Jews to ask: Where was God? Then, in 1948, out of the tragedy of the Holocaust, against all odds, the State of Israel was re-established by the mighty hand of God. This represented for the Jews the restoration of their homeland after a diaspora of almost two millennia. This miraculous turn of events prompted many Christians to revise their interpretation of Romans 9-11.

History serves to remind us to exercise humility in our interpretation of Scriptures. God's ways are much higher than ours. Even when we cannot comprehend the mysteries of His ways, we can still fully rest in the assurance of His faithfulness.
24 AUGUST.part7: O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! how unsearchable are his judgments, and his ways past finding out! - Romans 11:33

25 AUGUST.part4: I say then, Hath God cast away his people? God forbid. For I also am an Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.
25 AUGUST.part5:
Has God cast away His people? Paul responds with "God forbid", which in the original Greek is the most emphatic way one can say "No!" In other words, this suggestion is so outrageous that it should not even cross our minds as a possibility. Under no circumstances whatsoever would God abandon Israel!

Why does Paul use such a strong term? Because Paul has a high view of God. The conclusion that God has rejected His people may seem logical but has profound implications. If God has rejected Israel, it would mean God's Word has failed, that He is unable to keep His promises because His people refused to cooperate. If God has rejected Israel, it would imply that God is unfaithful to His covenant. Believers can have no eternal security in Christ because just as God has cast off Israel, God may also break His promises to us and cast us off. So, to suggest that God has rejected Israel is to undermine God's character and cast doubts on His sovereignty, power, faithfulness, and trustworthiness. How can we entertain such ideas? God forbid!

God is faithful to His covenant. Even when we are faithless, He remains faithful. His faithfulness endures to all generations. All His promises are true and will come to pass. All these are plainly written in the Bible, and we affirm them as believers. But when circumstances seem otherwise and doubts and storms assail us, will we still hold fast to our faith and uphold a high view of God? May the Lord help us.
25 AUGUST.part7: Know therefore that the LORD thy God, he is God, the faithful God, which keepeth covenant and mercy with them that love him and keep his commandments to a thousand generations. - Deuteronomy 7:9

26 AUGUST.part2: What Is the Future of Israel?
26 AUGUST.part4: I say then, Hath God cast away his people? God forbid. For I also am an Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.
26 AUGUST.part5:
Much has been said about the nation of Israel. First, Paul has made it clear that not all Israel is Israel. Only those who have come to a saving faith in Christ are the true children of God. Although Israel as a whole has rejected Christ, God continues to preserve a remnant of true believers within Israel by His grace.

At the same time, Paul reaffirms God's election of the nation of Israel. God has not rejected Israel. The nation of Israel continues to have a role in God's salvation plan. The spiritual hardening that has come upon Israel because of her rejection of Christ is only temporary and partial. When the full number of the Gentiles has come in, "all Israel shall be saved" [v. 26]. There will be a future restoration of the nation of Israel, both spiritual and geographical. God will fulfil His promises to Israel and restore her to her homeland. God will also take away her spiritual hardness, and Israel as a whole will come to a saving faith in Christ.

We do not know precisely when and how the conversion of Israel's hardened majority will take place. God's wisdom and ways are deep and unsearchable. But what is clear is that the same compassion and kindness of God lies behind His dealings with Israel and His dealings with the church. God mercifully gave salvation to both Jews and the Gentiles even though none deserve it. Knowing this ought to move us to praise and worship Him, and give Him all the glory for our salvation.
26 AUGUST.part7: For I know the thoughts that I think toward you, saith the LORD, thoughts of peace, and not of evil, to give you an expected end. - Jeremiah 29:11

27 AUGUST.part4: God hath not cast away his people which he foreknew. Wot ye not what the scripture saith of Elias? how he maketh intercession to God against Israel, saying,
27 AUGUST.part5:
The fact that Paul, an Israelite, believed God showed that Israel was not completely lost. The people God foreknew refers here to those among the children of Israel who followed Him. God had chosen Israel in love when they were few in number.

"The LORD did not set his love upon you, nor choose you, because ye were more in number than any people; for ye were the fewest of all people" [Deuternomy 7:7].

God prospered Jacob and his family from a group of 70 going down to Egypt to become a great multitude. He preserved them through Egyptian slavery, sent His servant Moses with His message, delivered them by His hand from the military superpower of their day, fed them and provided for them, protected and guided them in the wilderness, and brought them to the verge of entering the promised land of Canaan. He had taught them His ways, His character, and how to worship Him. The people were disobedient in not trusting the God who chose them. Their rebellion resulted in them wandering in the wilderness wandering for 40 years, and the death of all who were 20 years and older except for Joshua and Caleb. Through the course of their history, they persecuted and even killed Jehovah's prophets sent in love, for they rejected the LORD Himself.

Despite this, God did not totally reject them, as there were in their midst some whom God had chosen to save. These are the foreknown people of God, to whom He binds Himself in a covenant He will not break. His will is to save His foreknown to be a special people set apart for His praise and glory. [Deuteronomy 7:6; 1 Peter 2:9].
27 AUGUST.part7: Heavenly Father forgive us for our rebelliousness, unfaithfulness and being stiff-necked. We praise You for Your mercy in not rejecting us and Your grace in saving us for You have foreknown us to be saved in Your Son our Lord Jesus Christ.

28 AUGUST.part4: God hath not cast away his people which he foreknew. Wot ye not what the scripture saith of Elias? how he maketh intercession to God against Israel, saying,
28 AUGUST.part5:
Paul refers to the historic event when Elijah face-off against the prophets of Baal at Mount Carmel in a contest [1 Kings 18]. From morning till evening, the false prophets prayed to Baal for fire to burn the bullock sacrifice, pleading and cutting themselves in vain. Baal did not respond for he is but a man-made idol. Foolishly, the Israelites had forsaken Jehovah to worship Baal! As proof He is the true LORD God of Israel, and Elijah His prophet, God sent fire from Heaven burning and consuming the water-drenched bullock, wood, stone, earth and water. Obeying Elijah's call, the observing Israelites slew the false prophets by the brook of Kishon. Evil Queen Jezebel hearing of the prophets' end then sent a murderous message to Elijah vowing vengeance for his deeds.

Despite having great faith and courage at Mount Carmel, Elijah fled into the wilderness, despairing and calling on God to take his life. God did not rebuke His servant but sent an angel to provide nourishment, instructing him to rest to gather strength for the journey to Mount Horeb. In response to God asking what he was doing there, Elijah replied: "I have been very jealous for the LORD God of hosts: for the children of Israel have forsaken thy covenant, thrown down thine altars, and slain thy prophets with the sword; and I, even I only, am left; and they seek my life, to take it away." [1 Kings 19:10,14]. Elijah was utterly discouraged and despairing of Israel's idolatry. Being "jealous for God" here is to be very fervent, zealous, and careful in protecting the glory of God's name. He had been faithful to God but felt alone in this. This drove him to the point of depression and desiring God to take his life.
28 AUGUST.part7: Obey them that have the rule over you, and submit yourselves: for they watch for your souls, as they that must give account, that they may do it with joy, and not with grief: for that is unprofitable for you. - Hebrews 13:17

29 AUGUST.part4: God hath not cast away his people which he foreknew. Wot ye not what the scripture saith of Elias? how he maketh intercession to God against Israel, saying, Lord, they have killed thy prophets, and digged down thine altars; and I am left alone, and they seek my life.
29 AUGUST.part5:
Elijah cried out for God to hold the children of Israel accountable for forsaking Him, destroying the worship altars, and killing His messengers. Elijah had a zeal for God because of who He is and what He had done for His covenant people, and yet they had forsaken Him. Elijah was zealous for God's glory. Are you?

"Ye shall not go after other gods, of the gods of the people which are round about you; (For the LORD thy God is a jealous God among you) lest the anger of the LORD thy God be kindled against thee, and destroy thee from off the face of the earth" [Deuteronomy 6:14-15].

Imprecatory prayer invokes curses and punishment by God upon His enemies. It is not for selfish vengeful purposes of the servant of God for being wronged personally. Imprecatory psalms [Psalms 7, 35, 55, 58, 69, 109 and 139] called on God to judge His enemies and protect His people, emphasizing His holiness, purity, abhorrence of evil, whilst submitting to His sovereign wisdom and will. The one who prays conducts self-examination before God, acknowledges their position as His servant, calling on Him to be true to His promise to protect His people for His name's sake. There is no wilful, selfish desire for personal vengeance nor trying to manipulate God for one's own ends.

"The LORD shall judge the people: judge me, O LORD, according to my righteousness, and according to mine integrity that is in me. Oh let the wickedness of the wicked come to an end; but establish the just: for the righteous God trieth the hearts and reins." [Psalm 7:8-9]
29 AUGUST.part7: "For the zeal of thine house hath eaten me up; and the reproaches of them that reproached thee are fallen upon me." Psalm 69:9 is the basis for imprecatory prayer.

30 AUGUST.part4: But what saith the answer of God unto him? I have reserved to myself seven thousand men, who have not bowed the knee to the image of Baal.
30 AUGUST.part5:
God had sent an angel to provide food and water to strengthen Elijah, and command rest before the journey to Mount Horeb (a forty-day journey). There God showed His power by the gale-force winds which broke the mountainside, an earthquake and fire, all whilst preserving Elijah in the midst of these natural wonders wrought by His mighty hand, even though God was not in these. When all that was past, God spoke in a still small voice to Elijah, and he went to the mouth of the cave [1 Kings 19].

He instructed His servant to anoint Hazael king over Syria; Jehu king over Israel; and Elisha to be prophet in Elijah's place. They would continue God's work.

God reveals to His faithful but discouraged prophet there were seven thousand men unbeknownst to Elijah who were still faithful to Jehovah. God did not mollycoddle the prophet but revealed Himself, strengthened him to do His work, and gave further instructions how to carry it out. God personally answering Elijah showed he was loved, and that was encouragement and reassurance in itself. The content of this personal message revealed that he was not alone (as he thought) and that God had preserved a remnant for Himself. Further instructions removed doubt and gave direction to the ailing prophet.

God's answer was not only encouragement to Elijah but to us if we are discouraged in His service. The LORD God of Israel is working His purposes even when we cannot see it. God is continuing to watch over His people in times of discouragement and trouble. He will never forsake us and He continues to bless His work in His way and time, to the glory of His name. We are to faithfully obey.
30 AUGUST.part7: Blessed is the man whose strength is in thee; in whose heart are the ways of them. They go from strength to strength, every one of them in Zion appeareth before God. - Psalm 84:5, 7

31 AUGUST.part4: Even so then at this present time also there is a remnant according to the election of grace.
31 AUGUST.part5:
The remnant is foreknown by God, and who are preserved by Him for they were elected by His grace. God will always preserve a remnant for Himself. Throughout God's Word, we see the examples of Noah and his family in the ark preserved [Genesis 6] when the living world was destroyed; the seven thousand faithful apart from Elijah [1 Kings 19] when the nation apostatized, and God bringing back exiles from the Babylonian captivity [Ezra 2] according to His promise [Isaiah 6:13], amongst many others. As it was in the time of Elijah, and of Paul's writing, it is so even today as you read this.

"Who is a God like unto thee, that pardoneth iniquity, and passeth by the transgression of the remnant of his heritage? he retaineth not his anger for ever, because he delighteth in mercy." [Micah 7:18]

"Remnant" implies a small number out of a larger group. The faithful remnant of the nation of Israel worshipped Jehovah as the LORD God of Israel in the days of Elijah. They did so for they were chosen and sustained by God's grace.

Apart from many who reject the good news of salvation in the Lord Jesus Christ the only begotten Son of God, there will always be those who believe, and call on His name in repentance for their sins. This remnant is elected of God's grace. These constitute the spiritual Israel, the true Church of God, and include Israelites as well as Gentiles.

"And it shall come to pass, that whosoever shall call on the name of the LORD shall be delivered: for in mount Zion and in Jerusalem shall be deliverance, as the LORD hath said, and in the remnant whom the LORD shall call." [Joel 2:32]
31 AUGUST.part7: And I will gather the remnant of my flock out of all countries whither I have driven them, and will bring them again to their folds; and they shall be fruitful and increase. - Jeremiah 23:3

1 SEPTEMBER.part7: And if by grace, then is it no more of works: otherwise grace is no more grace. But if it be of works, then is it no more grace: otherwise work is no more work.  THOUGHT  f a debt has been fully repaid, there is nothing further to be settled. If you have a debt of one hundred dollars and your brother repays it and presents you with a receipt for the full amount, you have no more obligation to your creditor. The debt has been fully satisfied. No part of it can thereafter be charged against you. If the Lord Jesus Christ paid for the full guilt of our sins, there is no guilt left to be paid for in any other way. Repentance does not pay for sin, baptism does not, neither does any other religious act pay for sin. What a wonderful picture that God acts towards us according to what is entirely found within His own divine nature of love. When God chose the Israelites to be His people in Deuteronomy 7:8 it was not based on their strength, intellect, character, or their achievements, but "because the LORD loved (them)." Neither does God look down the corridors of time to see how we would respond to the call of faith in Jesus Christ as that would suggest something originating from us (our response) is the determinant of our salvation. It is all of God's grace; His unmerited favour bestowed upon unworthy sinners. At the cross, our sins were put upon Jesus Christ as if He had committed those sins, and His righteousness was put upon us as if we had lived His life, so that we might be presented blameless in the sight of God.  Dear God, please help me to release any claim of self-righteousness, and rest completely on Your grace alone.

2 SEPTEMBER.part7: And if by grace, then is it no more of works: otherwise grace is no more grace. But if it be of works, then is it no more grace: otherwise work is no more work.  THOUGHT  he word "works" refers to anything that human beings do. If we could by our works secure God's blessing, then grace would "no more" be grace. For grace demands that God be perfectly free to bestow His favour on whomever He chooses. But if God's election were based on what we do, His freedom would be violated, and He would no longer be acting in grace. We must strive to keep grace gracious. Paul affirms that God has called a remnant [v. 5] in his present time; however, this remnant has come into being as the result of God's gracious election. It is not due to Israel's intrinsic merit or their achievement in obeying the law. Jews are no different from Gentiles on this point: only by God's gracious intervention can they be transformed from sinners doomed to die into righteous people destined for eternal life. Because salvation is by grace, works have no part in it. The whole idea of works is that man can provide a basis to force God to give him some blessing as just reward for what he has done. The whole idea of grace is that God acts toward man entirely according to that which is found within His own divine nature of love. The two ideas are mutually exclusive and destroy each other when put together. May this remind us that our upbringing, our merits, and our righteousness does nothing to tip the scales to earn the undeserved mercy of God.  Not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to his mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the Holy Ghost. - Titus 3:5

3 SEPTEMBER.part3: VERSE 6 and sovereignly preserved in the faith. God has
3 SEPTEMBER.part7: And if by grace, then is it no more of works: otherwise grace is no more grace. But if it be of works, then is it no more grace: otherwise work is no more work.  THOUGHT  aul's argument leaves no room for work-based salvation. Anything less than grace alone sneaks human works in through the back door. From start to finish, from election to conversion to heaven, salvation is by God's grace alone. Salvation is based solely on God's gracious love and mercy, not on the basis of a human decision or human works. By grace, believers are sovereignly drawn to the faith, and sovereignly preserved in the faith. God has accomplished everything that is necessary for the believer's salvation. What this means is that salvation is personal. God chose those whom He would call. Man had no part in it. If Christ purchased a sinner's salvation based on his action or choice, then man's work is injected into the equation. Rather, salvation is for a particular people whom God sovereignly chose on the basis of His grace alone. And because it is by grace alone, believers can only attribute all praise and glory to God. When salvation is of the Lord and not from anything within us, the only possible response is to fall on our knees before God in humble adoration and awe at His eternal purpose. We cry out with thankful hearts the words of the hymn writer Charles Wesley, "How can it be that thou, my God, should die for me?"  But no man can be thoroughly humbled until he knows that his salvation is utterly beyond his own powers, devices, endeavours, will, and works, and depends entirely on the choice, will, and work of another, namely, of God alone ... then he has come close to grace, and can be saved. - Martin Luther

4 SEPTEMBER.part7: What then? Israel hath not obtained that which he seeketh for; but the election hath obtained it, and the rest were blinded.  THOUGHT  I once was lost, but now I'm found, was blind but now I see." When John Newton penned the words of the hymn "Amazing Grace", he was describing himself. Likewise, Paul describes a blindness of those who were not chosen by God. The word "blinded" in the original language is the word for "hardened", meaning to "cover with a thick skin". Just as Pharaoh's heart was hardened, so too are the hearts of those who are not elected. Out of their spiritual blindness and the hardness of their hearts, these people tried to seek righteousness and life by the works of the law. Be assured when you read about God "hardening hearts", the Bible is not saying God arbitrarily and maliciously makes men unbelievers. The non-elect - those who are hardened - are not passed over because they are worse. And the elect are not chosen because they are better. Otherwise, grace would not be grace. However, we do know that God is the implied agent of the hardening so that there is a spiritual insensitivity that prevents people from responding to God and His message of salvation. The result of God's hardening permanently binds people in the sin they have chosen for themselves. The only solution is for God to take that stony heart and give us a heart of flesh [Ezekiel 36:26].  Let us be thankful that God has removed the veil from our eyes so that we can see who He is and understand what He has written to us.

5 SEPTEMBER.part3: VERSE 8 Although the Israelites witnessed the hand of God
5 SEPTEMBER.part7: (According as it is written, God hath given them the spirit of slumber, eyes that they should not see, and ears that they should not hear;) unto this day.  PRAYER  t is difficult to wake a person who is in deep sleep. Physically, they are dulled to any force that touches them externally. Paul here describes a person who is in spiritual deep sleep and dull and insensitive to God's many miraculous acts of grace; hence, not seeing and hearing. And Paul draws upon Old Testament texts by conflating Deuteronomy 29:4 and Isaiah 29:10 which comments on Israel's failure to recognize God's work among them. Although the Israelites witnessed the hand of God against Pharoah in their exodus from Egypt, they never appreciated its full significance. Paul also draws upon a passage in which Isaiah spoke of the spiritual blindness and perversity of Israel. This is the state of the world we live in. Unbelievers lie in a deep sleep and see not what is before them; they sleep and hear not the Gospel that is preached all over the earth. We too must be careful not to fall into a condition of moral dullness and apathy. Much prayer is required to ask that our eyes and hearts be open to know both the grace of God and the God of grace who is very much active in the present day. When we become tolerant of sin, distracted by the allures of the world, and self-dependent on our strength, this will cause us to become insensitive to God's providence and sovereignty in our lives.  God, open up my eyes that I may trust you, love you, treasure you, and humble me to see your gracious acts each and every day. Amen.

6 SEPTEMBER.part7: And David saith, Let their table be made a snare, and a trap, and a stumblingblock, and a recompence unto them:  THOUGHT  aul here quotes from Psalm 69:22-23. Importantly, David prays in verse 22 that "that which should have been for their welfare, let it become a trap." This is an important statement for us to reflect on. Often, Christians tend to think of ourselves as people who do not indulge in sins that are very grievous. We may not be the type of people who steal, kill or commit adultery. The Jews Paul talks about in Romans 11 possessed a similar mindset - having a semblance of piety that they believed restrained them from committing grievous sin. Like these Jews, Christians often overlook the fact that neutral things in our lives can also become stumbling blocks and occasions for sin. Let us realize that while God in His goodness has provided us many blessings to enjoy, such as food, leisure activities, and companionship, these things He gives for our well-being cannot and must not take His place in our hearts. Often, we become preoccupied with leisure activities such that we lie to ourselves that we do not have time to serve God. Even worse, it seems we seek our own pleasure and enjoyment in the lawful things of this world more than we seek to do God's will in serving Him and desiring a closer relationship with Him. Let us not deceive ourselves. It is idolatry in a subtle form when the lawful things God has given us to enjoy become snares, turning us away from Him.  You must therefore zealously guard in his mind the curious assumption 'My time is my own'. Let him have the feeling that he starts each day as the lawful possessor of twenty-four hours ... What he must never be permitted to doubt is that the total from which these deductions have been made was, in some mysterious sense, his own personal birthright. - C. S. Lewis in Screwtape Letters

7 SEPTEMBER.part7: Let their eyes be darkened, that they may not see, and bow down their back alway.  THOUGHT  n citing this verse, Paul is explaining that the reason the Jews rejected Christ and were so persistent in disbelieving He was the Messiah was because God had blinded their spiritual eyes, as foretold long ago by David. Paul's observation should cause us to respond in thankfulness. For just as God had been the one who blinded the eyes of the Jews, He is also the one who opened our spiritual eyes, that we may recognize and call Christ our Lord and Saviour. Now that we are able to receive, understand, and accept the things of God, let us also examine how we are exercising these gifts. In Isaiah 53:2-3 we are told how the spiritually blind are unable to see any beauty in Christ. Furthermore, we read how Isaiah prophesied that Christ would be despised and rejected because of the Jews' spiritual blindness. Do we see beauty in God's "things"? What does worshipping God in the beauty of holiness [Psalm 29:2; 96:9] mean to us? Do we delight in communal worship and fellowship with likeminded brethren or are we constantly dragging our feet to church? What is our attitude in our daily lives? Let us be sensitive to the manifold blessings of God, even for the many things we often take for granted. There is beauty in each sunrise, and there is God's mercy and grace received every time we return home safely.  Nevertheless he left not himself without witness, in that he did good, and gave us rain from heaven, and fruitful seasons, filling our hearts with food and gladness. - Acts 14:17

8 SEPTEMBER.part7: I say then, Have they stumbled that they should fall? God forbid: but rather through their fall salvation is come unto the Gentiles, for to provoke them to jealousy.  THOUGHT  od moves in mysterious ways. Many times, His purposes and intents are beyond mortal comprehension, and it is presumptuous for us to think we can understand Him fully. Here, however, God's inspired Word gives us some insight into why God caused the Jew's eyes to be blinded in unbelief. It was not so that the Jews would be permanently and eternally punished - God did not intend their stumbling to lead to their ultimate fall. Rather, God allowed them to stumble as a means of extending His grace to Gentiles. In some ways, this was a fitting comeuppance for the Jews who had long believed they were culturally superior to those around them because they were Abraham's descendants. In their pride, God allowed them to fall, choosing instead to save the humble and meek. From our perspective, however, this is wholly an act of grace towards us. Let us be humble and thankful for God's mercy extended to us. Furthermore, praise and thank Him that in His sovereign salvation plan, He has chosen to do away with the rituals and rites that were a large part of Jewish culture. Now we have free access to His throne of grace. THOUGHT  he writer uses two metaphors to illustrate God's people throughout Israel's history. He first quoted from the book of Numbers 15:18-21. For there is no difference between the Jew and the Greek: for the same Lord over all is rich unto all that call upon him. - Romans 10:12

That ye would walk worthy of God, who hath called you unto his kingdom and glory. - 1 Thessalonians 2:12

The Holy Spirit then reproves (convicts) us of sin, of righteousness, and of judgment to come. 21 SEPTEMBER.part7: Thou wilt say then, The branches were broken off, that I might be graffed in.  THOUGHT  n horticulture, farmers employ the technique of grafting to join together two different plants for beneficial results. In grafting, parts such as a bud or a stem are taken from a plant and joined together with another plant such that the nutrients from the main plant nourishes the part that is grafted in. In this way, the new branch grows and yields desirable characteristics such as better fruits or flowers. One of the reasons for grafting may be that the grafted plant has weak roots, and this procedure provides a strong root-stock to sustain the fruit-bearing or flower-producing part of the desired plant. This is a good analogy for the Christian believers and Romans 11:19 uses this analogy to describe the relationship between Christ and the believer. Christ being the root, and the believer the branches thereof. In the process of grafting, some of the original branches are broken off, so that the new branch can be grafted in its place. In Jesus' parable in Matthew 22, the original wedding guests refused to attend the wedding celebrations. Therefore, the king bid his servants to invite as many as they could find from the highways and byways to attend the wedding dinner instead. Similarly, when the Jews refused the preaching of the Gospel, Paul brought it to the Gentiles instead. Let us rejoice, therefore, that the Gospel was made available to all. Just like the plants, we are all grafted into the root which is Jesus Christ, so let us draw our strength from Him.  But now in Christ Jesus ye who sometimes were far off are made nigh by the blood of Christ. - Ephesians 2:13.

Have you considered your heart today and search it to see if there is unbelief lurking within? Most translations use "severity," perhaps an apt wordplay between "severe" and "sever". Indeed, the severity of God would result in the cutting off of disobedient people from His lovingkindness. It brings out the consequences of going against the true and living God. However, the context of this verse is not personal salvation. Rather, God is speaking to the Jews and Gentiles as two groups of people, and the fellowship they could have with God. Because of the hard-heartedness of the Jews, the Gospel was opened to the Gentiles. God then warns the Gentiles that if they prove to be as unteachable, they shall also be cut off; they will face the same severity as the Jews. This is not to say that our God is a passive God who reacts to our responses to the Gospel. Our sovereign God is outside time but has chosen to work within it. Outside time, God sees everything in an instant - past, present, and future. Yet God, when relating to us who live in time, reveals things in a way we can understand. In God's sovereign plan, the ends of the Jews and the Gentiles have already been ordained. God's instruction is clearly made known in the Gospel to all, both Jews and Gentiles: the severity of God points to separation and judgment, but the goodness of God shows us salvation and righteousness. But all is not lost, for verse 23 will tell us, God is able to graft in the branches that were pruned. While there is still time, trust in the Lord Jesus and be saved. The Lord is not slack concerning his promise, as some men count slackness; but is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance. - 2 Peter 3:9

28 SEPTEMBER.part7: And they also, if they abide not still in unbelief, shall be graffed in: for God is able to graff them in again.  THOUGHT  he Jews occupy a special place in God's plan. The historical account of the Old Testament is largely a chronicle of Jewish history. God the Son was born a Jew when He first came to this world. Yet like all sinful men in this fallen world, the Jews stood against God when they rejected the Messiah. Paul used the analogy of a branch cut off from a tree to show the broken fellowship between them and God. Because of their disobedience, the Gospel of Christ was given to the Gentiles. What will happen to the Jews then? Today's verse tells us there is still hope of salvation for this precious group of people. If they do not remain in unbelief, God is able to graft them back to the tree. Grafting is a technique in botany where a cutaway branch is bound to a living tree, and receiving nutrients and water from it, grow and bear fruit. God's desiderative will is for every man, Jew and Gentile, to know Him and to be saved. The mercy He showered upon Gentiles could provoke the Jews to also believe in Him. If they were to repent and trust in Jesus, it is akin to the branch once cut off and bound for burning, to be given life again. Our omnipotent God is able to do that. Just as He was able to give life to the dry bones in the valley [Ezekiel 37:1-14], He is able to give life to all who are dead in sin and trespasses. All praise and glory will be to God for the branch cannot rejoin itself to the tree on its own accord. The gracious God has to hold it and bind it to the tree.  For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek. For therein is the righteousness of God revealed from faith to faith: as it is written, The just shall live by faith. - Romans 1:16-17

29 SEPTEMBER.part7: For if thou wert cut out of the olive tree which is wild by nature, and wert graffed contrary to nature into a good olive tree: how much more shall these, which be the natural branches, be graffed into their own olive tree?  THOUGHT  hen you see a beautifully manicured plant you can be sure someone has shaped it. By the laws of nature, plants grow wild. New shoots will grow towards unblocked space, and the branches will eventually look messy. If you do not tend to your garden, plants will soon grow wild, and it will turn into an unrecognizable plot. The tasty fruits we buy are not harvested from the wild because wild free-growing trees bear little good fruits. In this verse, God uses the olive tree as an example and lesson for the Jews as well as Gentiles. Like the olive tree, man is also by nature wild. We will do things that are right in our own eyes. We will do what we like regardless of whether it hurts others or offends God. We are not interested to look for God or to please Him. In fact, we are often hostile towards Him. Selfishly, we want to please ourselves. We are unfruitful. We see in the Bible that man rebelled against God. Adam ate the fruit despite God telling him not to. Cain killed his brother Abel for a selfish reason. Disobedient and without God in mind, the people built the tower of Babel to reach the heavens (but it failed miserably). Instead of being grateful, the Israelites complained that the manna (which fell from the sky freely) was boring food. There are many examples for us to learn from, yet man disbelieves God's Word. This is the wild nature of man. Yet in spite of our rebelliousness, God deals with us according to His grace and mercy. He did not write us off. We can only thank God for His love.  Every way of a man is right in his own eyes: but the LORD pondereth the hearts. - Proverbs 21:2

30 SEPTEMBER.part7: For if thou wert cut out of the olive tree which is wild by nature, and wert graffed contrary to nature into a good olive tree: how much more shall these, which be the natural branches, be graffed into their own olive tree?  THOUGHT  od has a remedy for the olive tree that grows wild by nature. Like a good farmer, He grafted the wild olive branch to a very good stock, a perfect one you may say. Mankind falls short of God's glory and can never enter heaven. But thanks be to God, we are grafted into Jesus the incorrupt branch and as the new branch takes over, we surrender our will to God. We are no longer wild-willed. We are transformed into a new tree. "Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature" [2 Corinthians 5:17a]. We no longer live according to the dictates of the old self but live a regenerated life. Our priorities change and we become fruitful. We are now joined to the incorruptible tree as the great family of God. We are to bear spiritual fruits since we are transformed and no longer wild. The Bible reminds us to bear the fruit of the Spirit, which is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, meekness, temperance and be a faithful and obedient servant. The grafting of the olive tree is an object lesson. The tree was originally meant for the Jews but they rejected Christ and were cut off. In their place was grafted the wild olive branch (Gentiles like us). Do not despise the Jews or be proud of yourselves for being selected. It is solely by God's grace we were chosen.  For the wages of sin is death; but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord. - Romans 6:23
